 19 2. THE PROJECT A. PROJECT ORIGIN AND CONCEPT 2.1 At the Mid-Term Review of the RRMIMP-1 project in May 1992 it was agreed to prepare a new rural infrastructure Improvement project as a follow-up to continue similar programs. The concept of the proposed project has been developed during the course of the ongoing project and of IDA's review of the GOB rural infrastructure strategy, which highlights continued need to invest on improving rural infrastructure. GOB's and IDA's review of agriculture strategy also emphasizes rural infrastructure improvements as a priority. Much has been learnt from the experience of the RRMIMP- 1 (see para. 1.53), and from the simultaneous SDC-financed rural development project (RDP-6) in Manikganj District of Greater Dhaka, and also from other RDPs. During the period of implementation of these projects the LGED has grown and evolved rapidly as an effective, rural infrastructure development institution. 2.2 The proposed RRMIMP-2 project will be co-financed with the SDC and will include additional physical works in the Northwest Region but with greater emphasis on works in the contiguous Greater Dhaka Area where there has been only limited rural infrastructure investment to date. As noted, individual projects under RDP series focus on infrastructure needs of particular regions, funded by different agencies, well coordinated by LGED. The project area for RRMIMP-2 was selected for the following reasons: (a) continuity with on-going IDA and SDC work; (b) relatively higher poverty level; (c) absence of any previous RDP in the Greater Dhaka Area (except in one District); and (d) poor infrastructure conditions in the whole project area. B. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 2.3 The overall development objective of the proposed project is to help increase rural employment and incomes and reduce rural poverty by establishing an improved, sustainable rural transport and trading infrastructure. More specifically, the project objectives would be to: (a) help remove physical bottlenecks, improve quality, and reduce costs in rural transport and marketing; (b) create employment and income-generating opportunities among the rural poor, and particularly for disadvantaged women; (c) promote participation of local communities and NGOs in project activities; and (d) increase institutional capacity for efficient rural infrastructure management, including maintenance; 2.4 Performance indicators for monitoring progress in achieving the project objectives are given in Annex 3.7. C. RATIONALE FOR IDA INVOLVEMENT 2.5 The project would support GOB's and IDA's overall strategy to increase agricultural production and rural incomes, and to reduce poverty through removing rural infrastructure constraints. IDA's Strategy for the Transport Sector and rural infrastructure in Bangladesh follows the 1995
 20 Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) discussed by IDA Board in September 1995, which emphasized improving physical infrastructure, their maintenance, and related services, as they are critical for both international competitiveness of exports and the growth of agriculture and rural incomes. It also emphasized, for rural infrastructure, encouraging greater participation by local communities, increasing resource mobilization, adopting national standards, and strengthening local contractors. CAS also stresses labor-intensive growth, and special measures for poverty-alleviation. The proposed RRMIMP- 2, which relies on appropriate labor-intensive technology for most civil works with special provisions for employing the poor, and which gives high priority for improving rural infrastructure and community involvement is fully consistent with the CAS. 2.6 The ongoing project, RRMIMP-1, has set many good, new standards in rural road design specifications and maintenance; it is important to provide continuity by replicating them in other areas and by building on institutional and policy gains already achieved through the first project so as to keep the momentum of progress in rural development going at an accelerated pace. IDA's involvement, which is much appreciated by the Government and other donors, will provide such continuity. IDA support is needed also to: (a) encourage appropriate technology, cost-effective standards; and sustainable maintenance systems, (b) attract cofinancing support; and (c) help implement the findings of the IDA/GOB rural infrastructure study. D. PROJECT DESCRIPTION Project Components 2.7 The main components of the project are: (i) improvement and upgrading of about 575 km of feeder roads Type B (FRBs) in the Project Area (14 districts in the Northwest and Greater Dhaka areas, see para. 2.9), with small bridges, culverts and tree planting alongside the roads. It also includes bridges and culverts on other FRB roads not selected for full improvement, and road safety improvements; (ii) establishment and implementation of a planned routine and periodic maintenance system for the LGED road network in the project area covering all FRB roads, important RR1 roads, and structures on rural roads for replication nationally in the following years; (iii) construction of about 6000 culverts and small bridges (about 31,600 linear meters) of drainage structures on existing rural roads (mainly RR1 & RR2) (Nationwide), together with ancillary earthworks, which will fill existing gaps on about 10,500 km of rural roads and make them passable year-round, and also correct drainage problems created by existing rural roads; this component will particularly emphasize local participation, use of labor-intensive technologies, and employment of landless poor and disadvantaged women; (iv) improvement of rural markets (i.e., raised and covered sales platforms, walkways, drainage, potable water supply, sanitation) in about 136 growth center markets in the project area, and improvement of about 14 UP center markets in the project area; (v) rehabilitation/construction of 41 priority river jetties, or river 'ghats', in the project area, to improve landing/unloading facilities for country boats;
 21 (vi) pilot program to improve safety and efficiency of NMT, particularly rickshaw vans and passenger rickshaws, which are extensively used in the country in the movement of goods and passengers in rural areas, with participation of appropriate NGOs; (vii) supply of equipment for road construction and maintenance, of vehicles for supervision of works, and of office and training equipment; (viii) institutional and human resources development for increasing and strengthening managerial and technical capacity of LGED, local Government agencies, and the local construction industry, including support for fiscal and technical audits; and; (ix) implementation support including technical assistance for the design, supervision, monitoring and evaluation of annual work programs, and support for a follow-up rural infrastructure project preparation. 2.8 The additional features in this project compared to the first are: addition of river transport and integration of rural transport; support for improving non-motorized transport; more community participation, raising more local resources and more emphasis on rural drainage structures on existing rural roads; and greater emphasis on maintenance, and on adoption of national standards in construction and maintenance. The proposed project, in design and concept, will provide the cornerstone for a new generation of road transport and infrastructure projects; it will build on experience and lessons learned from the ongoing RRMIMP-1, and will complement and reinforce its achievements. Project Area 2.9 The project area (Map IBRD No. 27808) covers 14 Districts of Bangladesh (out of total 64) comprising: (a) six Districts of Greater Dhaka Area (Map IBRD No.27727) - Manikganj, Munshiganj, Narayanganj, Gazipur, Narshingdi and Dhaka Districts - of which only Manikganj District has benefited from other RDPs; and (b) eight districts of the Northwest Region (Map IBRD No. 27726) - Rajshahi, Naogaon, Natore, Nawabganj, Pabna, Sirajganj, Bogra and Joypurhat Districts - which already benefit from the ongoing RRMIMP-1 in the Northwest Region. The Northwest Area has 64 Thanas and 608 Union Parishads (UPs), and the Greater Dhaka Area has 33 Thanas and 361 UPs. In addition, the rural structure component (25 % of the project cost) covers all UPs in the whole country. 2.10 The project area covers about 25,000 sq. km and has a population of about 22 million people within this area. The Northwest Area is larger (72% of the land area) but less densely populated (62% of the population) than the Greater Dhaka Area. The construction of the Jamuna Multi-Purpose Bridge will significantly improve communications between the Northwest Region and the rest of the country, and create opportunities for economic development. The rural road network in the project area comprises about 3200 km of FRB, and 29,800 km of rural roads (9,450 km of RR1, 10,150 km of R2 and 10,200 km of R3), and there is a total of 425 growth center markets. By mid-1997, when the RRMIMP-1 and the SDC financed RDP-6 (which covers Manikganj) projects end, about 31 % of the FRB network (39% in the Northwest Region and 14% in the Greater Dhaka Area) will be in good, bitumen-surfaced condition, and 18% of the growth center Markets (25% in the Northwest Region, 6% in the Greater Dhaka Area) will have been improved. Even after the completion of the proposed project, the total coverage of rural infrastructure improvement needs in these 14 districts will be about 50-60%.
 22 Detailed Features (a) Improvement and Upgrading Feeder Roads B: (Base cost US$58.60 million) 2.11 Many FRBs in the project area are earthen embankments - most of them constructed under food for work programs but without mechanical compaction - often with unspanned 'gaps' across rivers and flood land. Some FRBs have been paved with Herring Bone Bond brick (HBB) but often without full compaction of the embankment resulting in a rough riding surface, and a few sections have been given a bituminous seal. The project would improve and upgrade about 574 km FRB roads (312 km in the Greater Dhaka Area and 262 km are in the Northwest Region on about 69 roads in all), including construction of 1915 metres of bridges and culverts, to provide all-weather road access to serve rural growth center markets. In addition to the full improvement and upgrading of FRB roads to bitumen-surfaced standards (including all necessary structures), the project includes a sub-component 'construction of structures on other FRB roads'. This reflects the need to bridge existing gaps and replace damaged structures on some of the other FRBs not selected for full upgrading in order to extend the mobility on the FRB road network in the project area. This would comprise construction of about 1,750 linear meters of small bridges and structures; two-third of these, will be in the more riverine Greater Dhaka Area. The project would include provision for improved road safety. 2.12 The FRB roads and structures have been selected using a participatory approach involving consultation with local bodies - UPs, TDCCs and NGOs - to derive a short-list of roads based on local priorities, which were then subjected to economic appraisal. All selected roads have an EIRR greater than 12%. Structures larger than 30 linear meter span will be subjected to economic appraisal before bidding. The selection procedures and criteria, and implementation procedures and time-frame, using active involvement of beneficiaries, based on specially designed participatory processes (para 3.1) for proposed physical investment schemes under various project components are given in Annex 2. 1; these criteria, procedures and pro grams were agreed during negotiations. Most FRB roads and FRB structures have been selected; if changes are needed they will follow the agreed selection criteria, and the changes will be reviewed during mid-term review. The list of proposed FRB roads, markets and river jetties, is given in Annex 2.2; this was confirmed during negotiations. 2.13 The proposed FRB design standards (PID-3) are based on the design standards of ongoing RRMIMP-1, with refinements made in the light of experience for various RDPs and trials. The pavement structure will comprise an improved sub-grade, coarse aggregate (brick) sub-base and water bound macadam (WBM) base course using brick aggregate, and a 25 mm bituminous carpeting (BC) surface. In specific circumstances where the traffic level on FRB is high, the thickness of BC will be increased to 40 mm provided if it is economically justified, and where the traffic level on FRB is low, the thickness of the BC will be reduced to 15 mm. The surfacing specification of providing 25 mm BC under normal traffic conditions, is based on a studies carried out by LGED and the consultants, on the performance of several trial sections of different specifications observed during the implementation phase of various RDPs. Furthermore the design of 25 mm BC for surface treatment on FRBs, has been determined from the extensive discussions held between the experts of IDAISDC and LGED in the context of all economical and technical implications involved in the selection of pavement thickness. A special factor to take into account in the context of Bangladesh is the fact that the broken bricks (used for surfacing in lieu of natural laterite stones due to non-availability of the latter) lacks plasticity to bond; such paving eliminates the risk of these surfacing materials being washed away in the heavy rains common in Bangladesh, thus giving longer life and lesser maintenance costs. It also significantly reduces the roughness of the surface, allowing the predominant cycle-rickshaws (human- pedaled) easy ridability; transport cost savings justified the additional cost on paving of these important roads. The project includes the construction of trial sections in order to promote the use of possible bitumen emulsions, which if successful can prove to be highly cost-effective in the construction of
 23 rural roads. The base course will be extended 600 mm on either side of the carriageway to provide a hard shoulder on both sides. This hard shoulder will protect the earth shoulder from damage during rains, and will also improve safety particularly under the prevailing conditions where the traffic is mix of motorized and non-motorized. 2.14 Groups of disadvantaged women will be contracted to plant and take care of the trees alongside FRB roads and to carry out routine maintenance of the embankment slopes and earth shoulders, thus creating long-term employment. Based on GOB policy, ownership of the trees will be arranged so that the income they generate provides revenue for the UPs and gives benefits to the destitute women caretakers. The project will also finance the construction of a new LGED District office/laboratory/workshop facility in Dhaka District (which is the one project district where LGED does not yet have such a facility) and improvement of existing facilities in other Districts. The technical standards and unit cost for various road construction activities are given in PID-3. (b) Road Maintenance: (Base cost US$10.76 million) 2.15 The project attaches great importance to building an adequate maintenance management system in the country, based on best practice and techniques. LGED received its first GOB annual revenue budget for maintenance in FY 1992/93, and the budget has increased progressively since then - Taka 300 million (US$7.5 million) in 1992/93, Taka 400 million (US$10.0 million) in 1993/94, Taka 550 million (US$13.8 million) in 1994/95 and Taka 650 million (US$16.3 million) in 1995/96. A Rural Infrastructure Maintenance Cell (RIMC) was established within LGED in 1992, and since then it has made considerable progress in establishing the framework for road maintenance by setting up a road inventory system, introducing national maintenance guidelines and establishing a training program. However actual maintenance works in the field is still inadequate in many respects and need improvements. The other main source for funding maintenance of rural roads is the CIDA/CARE Road Maintenance Program (RMP), which is designed as a poverty-alleviation program for destitute women. To complement and support its efforts for setting up an effective, planned periodic maintenance system, the project would provide 50% of the periodic maintenance costs in the project area on a declining percentage basis over the implementation period, starting 80% in the first three years and decreasing to 30% in the last two years. The project would finance: (a) TA for setting up and designing an effective and efficient management system in the project area, which would be part of the DSM consultant services (para. 2.38); and (b) provide partial funding of periodic maintenance in the project area. This assistance would be provided in coordination with RIMC's program and other ADB financed inputs for maintenance strengthening. 2.16 Tables 3 and 4 in the Annex 2.8 provides an estimate of the needs and costs (including unit cost) of routine and periodic maintenance within the project area over the project period. These figures will be used for preparing annual maintenance plans and budgets (see para. 2.17). These amounts will be revised by mutual agreement in the light of further studies planned to be carried out during project implementation. 2.17 The project also attaches significant importance to the routine and periodic maintenance of the national rural road network. RIMC is taking leadership in improving national maintenance strategy. The recently prepared GOB rural infrastructure strategy paper has projected that the country will need an annual recurrent cost (annualized routine and periodic maintenance costs) of about US$33 million equivalent in 1995-96, increasing to about US$73 million annually in ten years as the road network is upgraded requiring more maintenance (See Annex 1.4). Although GOB has increased its maintenance budget allocations substantially in the current year 1995/96 to US$16.3 million to meet full current needs compared with the allocations made in previous years (para. 2.15), it will need to make increases in this amount in future as maintenance capability increases. The estimated maintenance needs for

Based on some projection of continued UP and other project contributions (see Annex 1.4), and assuming the continuation of the RMP program, it has been estimated that Government's budget allocation for rural road maintenance will have to increase as a minimum to about US$21 million in 1997-98 and US$31 million in 2001-02. To get assurance of meeting full maintenance funding, agreement was obtained during negotiations that the GOB would provide adequate fundinig for meeting full routine and periodic maintenance costs for all maintainable FRBs. RRs and structures during the project period, and for this purpose would increase its budget allocation for rural road maintenance to US$21 million in 1997-98, and thereafter annually increase it by US$2.5 million up to the year 2001-02. It will also be agreed that in case the RMP program, which currently provides about US$11 million equivalent for rural infrastructure maintenance, is downsized or discontinued, the Government would provide additional budget allocation or ensure other funding to continue similar program and to make up for the resulting reduction in maintenance funding. These amounts will be revised by mutual agreement in the light of further studies planned to be carried out during project implementation. In addition, the poor rural roads which are not in a maintainable condition due to prolonged deterioration, are in the immediate need of rehabilitation. At present there is no separate line for rehabilitation works under LGED's budget system. It is therefore necessary that the GOB and LGED should include separate allocation for rehabilitation until the roads are improved and placed under a sustainable maintenance program. 2.18 Agreement was reached during negotiations that LGED would agree with IDA before June 30 of each year annual maintenance program for the project area for the following fiscal year; the program for 1996-97 would be provided by January 31, 1997. The annual maintenance program would include the estimated funding requirements for routine and periodic maintenance separately for FRB, RRs, and structures for the project area. In order to carry out maintenance operations more effectively and efficiently in the field, agreement was reached during negotiations that LGED would designate a maintenance engineer in each district and thana by March 31. 1997. In addition, as part of agreed implementation procedures (para. 2.12 and Annex 2.1), LGED would promote greater community participation in road maintenance, and for this purpose would, in consultation with IDA, pilot greater community involvement in maintenance in two districts, starting not later than June 30, 1998. LGED would also set up District-level road user committees in the project area (para. 3.2). (c) Construction of Drainage Structures on Rural Roads (SRR) (Base cost US$55.08 million) 2.19 This component, which is national in scope and not limited to the 14 districts, would assist through participatory process, to fill large number of gaps existing in the rural road network and will help local communities in removing a major constraint they face in rural transport; it will also help to build new drainage structures where existing roads block cross-drainage. In Bangladesh, there are about 40,000 gaps (200,000 linear meters), yet to be bridged on its rural road network, which make the roads fragmented and less effective for all-weather mobility. Since the central government has to focus on FRB improvements costing over US$1.5 billion over the next 10 years, the only solution would be for the UP's to raise own resources and take on their own initiative to fill these road gaps. These gaps force closure of roads in rainy season, and block smooth flow of traffic in fair season. The structures are good investments in reducing transport costs and mobility constraints in the rural areas and reducing waterlogging in farms. Because it involves a large number of small, dispersed investments where priorities are best defined locally, the SRR component provides the opportunity to encourage the participation of communities, local bodies and other interest groups in planning, decision-making and implementation. Field interviews show that there is enthusiasm among UP
 25 Chairmen to participate in this program. All the participatory aspects of the component are detailed in Annexes 2.1 and 2.3. This component, through participatory process, community ownership, and initial deposit by UPs to signal (para 2.22) their commitment, will start a new culture in the planning, development and maintenance of transportation infrastructure in the rural areas. 2.20 On the 16,000 km of RRI and RR2 roads in the main project area there are estimated to be 5,600 unspanned gaps with a total length of about 30,000 linear meters, and a further 3,400 existing structures, with a total length of about 14,000 linear meters, which are in poor or damaged condition and require replacement or repair. This equates to more than one gap or damaged structure for every 1.75 km of Rural Road. The project will finance the construction of about 6,000 structures (31,600 linear meters) on RRs all over the country - primarily pipe and slab culverts and small bridges - to span gaps and replace damaged structures, together with ancillary earthworks. It will also finance new structures where existing road embankments block drainage between farm areas. This will make about 10,500 km of seasonal rural roads into all-weather roads, thus enhancing the value of existing investments (one structure of US$8,000 releasing full economic use of about U$50,000 worth of investment on 1.75 km roads). The annual construction program, and its geographic scope, is presented in PID-2. It is expected that some of the structures will be built on R3 roads subject to UP's preferences. 2.21 An amount of about US$55.08 million as base cost, is allocated for this component, of which US$47.70 million equivalent is for drainage structures (culverts and small bridges not exceeding 20 m length) on rural roads, and about US$7.38 million equivalent for ancillary earth works on rural roads (as approaches to the structures or elsewhere on the rural roads). As an indicative figure (not restrictive), the average length (span) of culvert is likely to be 5 meters, at a cost of about US$8,000 equivalent. Technical standards for structures were developed under RRMIMP-1 and would be further improved as indicator in PID-3. (d) Improvement of Rural Markets: (Base cost US$10.69 million) 2.23 Growth center markets are focal points for the sale and processing of rural produce, for the distribution of agricultural inputs and consumer goods imported into rural areas, and for other economic and social activities. Unimproved markets are congested, unhygienic, dusty in the dry and muddy in the wet - a problem compounded by the fact that many markets are low-lying, close to rivers and not free-draining. Many markets trade in meat and fish, but without adequate facilities for hygienic operations. The project would finance basic infrastructure and improved common facilities at 136 growth center markets, 67 in the Greater Dhaka Area and 69 in the Northwest Region. The main improvements would include covered sheds for the sale of perishable goods, slaughter slabs, sales platform, internal roads and walkways within the market areas and connecting with the main feeder roads serving the market area, drains, latrines, garbage pits, provision of parking space and an office for market administration. Production of bio-gas from garbage pits will be tried on a pilot basis. The project would also include improvement of about 14 other rural markets - one in each project district - to be developed as model UP market centers with improved transport terminal facilities and access. 2.24 Priority has also been given to integrating road, inland water transport, and market improvements in order to enhance the efficient operation of the rural transport and trading network. The selection procedure, and criteria for markets are given in Annex 2.1, and the list of selected markets and is given in Annex 2.2. The design standards and costs for market improvements are detailed in PID-4. The 'Users Input' participatory approach will be applied to the detailed design of the markets, which will involve market vendors and other users in design. The user participation in selection and detailed design will develop a sense of local ownership of the improved markets. Additional participatory measures will be adopted to improve the operation of the markets. The UPs will contribute 10% of investment costs. The project will assist and support the formation of Market Management Committees, and will provide them with training and assistance in planning and managing the operation and maintenance of the improved markets. Maintenance will be financed from the lease revenue of improved markets which is allocated for this purpose and which is considered generally adequate (see para. 1.24). According to the implementation procedures agreed (para. 2.12), LGED/UPs will use participatory processes, involving market vendors, to improve the structure and operation of the existing Market Management Conmmittees, and to improve market leasing processes to enhance revenue. (e) Rehabilitation/Construction of River Jetties (Ghats): (Base cost US$2. 00 million) 2.25 Inland water transport (IWT) through country boats remains important for the rural movement of people and goods. The project will provide improved facilities for the safe, dry, loading and unloading of cargo and people at 41 rural river ghats, 14 in the Northwest Region and 27 in the Greater Dhaka Area which is more riverine. This will increase the efficiency of loading/unloading, increase the role of IWT, reduce transport costs, and will reduce the accidents, injuries and losses that presently occur during this process and will provide a healthy environment. This component emphasizes local participation in selection, detailed design and operation of the improved ghats, using the same methodology as for the growth center markets. The ghats to be improved have been selected by the same procedure as for the markets, and the UPs will contribute 10% of the costs of improvement. Attention has also been given to integrating ghat improvements with the improved FRB and market network. The selection procedures and criteria are given in Annex 2.1, the list of ghats in Annex 2.2, and their annual construction program is given in PID-5.
 27 2.26 The ghat improvements will consist of 'river-bank' facilities for safe loading and unloading and for mooring, and 'on-land' facilities comprising a paved area with drainage, footpaths, a passenger shed, clean water supply, sanitary latrines, garbage bins, a small administration office and an internal access road to connect the ghat to the nearby FRB or main road. The aim is to provide low-cost but effective river-bank facilities, and design standards will be evolved as the project develops practical experience of designing for different conditions. Most of the ghats selected for improvement serve Growth center markets, and their improvement will contribute to the integration of the water/road transport and trading network. Ghat users and boat operators will participate in the detailed design of the ghats, through application of the Users Input approach. Details of ghat designs and costs are in PID-5. All ghats construction works will be on public land, and all improved ghats will be operated through competitive leasing. Measures will be adopted to establish effective operation and maintenance of the ghats by the ghat management committees, using the same participatory procedures as for the markets component. Involvement of country boat operators/owners associations, one of the main user groups of ghats, in the management of the ghats will be emphasized. It was agreed as part of implementation procedures (para. 2.12) that GOB will: (a) cause ghat management committee to be established for all developed ghats before completion of each ghat improvement, modeled on the market management committees; (b) ensure that operation of these ghats and markets will have adequate user participation. (f) Pilot Program to Improve Non-Motorized Transport (NMT): (Base cost US$0.96 million) 2.27 NMT (rickshaw-vans, cycle-rickshaws, bicycles and bullock carts) play a very important role in rural transport system in Bangladesh (see para. 1.15). The project includes a pilot component for promoting safety and design improvements in rickshaw and rickshaw-vans (which carry more than 50% of rural road traffic) and bullock-cart wheels (which damage road pavement). This pilot component will focus on the development and introduction of improvements in the design of rickshaw vans, cycle rickshaws and bullock carts on making trial runs through user-groups to further improve designs through their feedback; and on measures to stimulate the provision of credit for the purchase of the improved designs. While there have previous efforts to improve designs, they were not supported by adequate field trials and promotion. The component, if successful, will increase the competitiveness and service level of rickshaw vans and passenger rickshaws by improving their performance, cost-efficiency, safety and load carrying capability, and will sustain and increase income- generation for the rural poor from rickshaw pulling, it will also reduce the efforts and hardship involved in rickshaw driving. The component will also help increase the efficiency and reduce the damage caused to improved roads by, bullock carts. 2.28 The pilot component will adopt a participatory approach to technical innovation. It will be implemented through experienced local NGOs and vehicle users, and can potentially make a major impact on rural transport in the long run. The approach will be to develop specific improvements to the design of cycle rickshaws and rickshaw-vans - e.g. bodies, braking and gear systems - which can be fitted to the existing rickshaws as well as incorporated into new vehicles. For bullock carts the emphasis will be on introducing wheel/axle assemblies using rubber tires. The improved designs will be disseminated through promotion, demonstration and training, in collaboration with the Bangladesh National Working Group of the International Forum for Rural Transport and Development (IFRTD, and other local NGOs and community groups. This will develop an informed network of organizations, including credit-financing NGO agencies, to assist the dissemination of the improved designs and to encourage the provision of loans for the purchase of the improved designs by the rural poor. The project will also provide for the mobility need assessments related to the improvement and operation of NMT. The design, strategy, related issues, implementation program and cost estimate for the proposed pilot NMT component are described in more detail in Annex 2.4.

The equipment to be provided under the project is listed in Annex 2.5. 2.30 The project will help develop, and introduce in the project area, through design improvements, innovative items of low-cost, appropriate, locally made equipment to improve the quality and efficiency of construction and maintenance activities. Examples are: (a) temperature-controlled bitumen heater, temperature-controlled aggregate heater, drum mixer and trolley - to improve the quality and efficiency of production and laying of batched quantities of BC; (b) bitumen sprayer for use with both hot bitumen and bitumen emulsion; (c) a mobile bitumen trolley to carry one drum of emulsion and with a hand pumped spray lance; (d) a manually propelled compaction roller to improve compaction for ancillary earthworks on Rural Roads. 2.31 The equipment produced under the project will ensure the timely completion of project because the small local contractors do not have their own equipment and largely depend on LGED equipment fleet. LGED fleet is not sufficient to meet the project requirements. The existing scale of rental charges for LGED equipment is not sufficient to recover their operating and replacement costs, though they are adequate to recover operating and original investment costs. In order to avoid low LGED rent rates, discouraging the contractors in buying their own equipment, and to encourage the private sector to enter the equipment rental market, agreement was reached during negotiations that GOB would: (a) ensure that charges for renting such equipment are sufficient to cover the maintenance and replacement costs of such equipment. and (b) make available to LGED annually, through budget allocations into a separate identifiable 'item' in LGED's budget, for maintenance and replacement costs of such equipment, funds equivalent to the estimated rent collections for the following financial year. To promote labor based methods and encourage local contractor to have their own equipment, project would help promote use of low-cost locally produced equipment (para. 2.30), and also provide mobilization advance to contractors to help purchase of own equipment. To ensure adequate quality control in the execution of civil works the project would also finance urgently needed laboratory and testing equipment. The DSM consultants would provide technical assistance to LGED to set up an efficient equipment management system. (h) Institutional and Human Resource Development: (Base cost US$3.54 million) 2.32 Technical Assistance (Capacity Building): The project will provide Technical assistance to strengthen the institutional capacity and capability of LGED, local government bodies and the private sector contracting industry. The main focus would be on training district and thana level staff in: (a) supervision, quality control and financial and reporting procedures; (b) maintenance planning and management; (c) implementation procedures for the SRR component; (d) the methodologies and procedures for enhancing local community and beneficiary participation with an emphasis on information sharing and "Users Input" approaches in the selection, design, operation and maintenance of investment schemes, and in (e) improving maintenance systems. The project will also develop the capability of local contractors through training in technical and management aspects of contracting, prompt payment of bills, progressive introduction of larger construction contracts, and measures to encourage contractor-ownership of construction equipment. It will also support NGOs active in improving the country boats operations in the informal sector, in extending information-sharing, safety

The experience gained in Socio-economic monitoring and evaluation (SEM&E) of the project effects under RRMIMP-1, would be further harmonized in order to develop better rural investment planning and policy making. Technical assistance will be provided through consultants (local and foreign) as part of Design, Supervision and Monitoring (DSM) consultants, and as additional specialists, and through training programs (internal and external). Further details are given in Annex 2.6. The training program will be reviewed during negotiations, which will be subjected to annual review before March 31 each year. 2.33 The project will support LGED efforts in its capacity building, and based on the MANCAPS recommendations (para. 1.42), the project would finance seven incremental high level staff positions given in (Annex 1.2), which have been found necessary to implement project activities and will form part of LGED's subsequently reorganized establishment. Agreement was reached with GOB that it would implement the MANCAPS (see para. 1.41) recommendations on: (i) improved financial management and internal auditing: (ii) reduction of span of control through more delegation of responsibilities, and creation of 6 regional offices headed by Superintending Engineer before March 31. 1997. The other details including MANCAPS recommendations and proposed organization chart for the management strengthening of LGED are given in Annex 1.2. 2.34 Technical Assistance (Policy Support): It is proposed to carry out the following studies on: (a) long-term socio-economic impact to evaluate and quantify the impacts of rural infrastructure investment in the project area on the transport and trading system, on economic and social development, and on poverty alleviation (which will supplement traffic impact studies carried out as part of SEM&E (see para. 1.53)); (b) small scale contracting industry to develop a better understanding of its financial, management and operating characteristics and of the constraints to its development; (c) study of pavement behavior of various trial sections constructed on FRB roads under the project; (d) road construction contractor unit costs to develop competitive unit cost rates for different construction activities; (e) Feeder Roads Regional prioritization study to define guidelines for the prioritization of FRBs rural roads and markets improvements and for reviewing roads classification; (f) financial resource mobilization of local bodies; (g) financial audit studies; and (h) technical audit studies. The outline TOR for the proposed studies is shown in Annex 2.7, with details in PID; these were reviewed and agreed during negotiations. 2.35 Development of Small Scale Construction Industry: LGED implements a large number of construction schemes including rural roads, structures and markets through award of contracts. The capacity of local construction industry largely consisting of petty contractors, is severely constrained on account of lack of contractor's owned construction equipment (rollers and trucks), training in contract procedures and management, and weak credit worthiness for receiving mobilization advances from LGED. Limited construction season, generally December to May, is another key factor which discourages the small contractors from buying construction equipment. In order to keep the contract size within the capacity of local contractors, and to help train them, LGED has been awarding contracts of smaller size (2-3 km with contract value not more than US$100,000) with the time limit of one construction season, and has also been giving their equipment on rent. The proposed project would encourage to enlarge the size of contracts by extending the time limit into two construction seasons. To strengthen the capability of local construction industry, the project will initiate several next steps including: (a) improving technical and management capacity of small contractors through training; (b) financing of equipment for leasing to contractors at commercial rates; (c) encouraging the contractors to own low-cost locally made construction equipment; (d) progressive increase in the size of contracts. To review these initiatives systematically, a study on small scale contracting industry

STATUS OF PROJECT PREPARATION 2.44 The LGED has prepared the project in the light of its considerable past experience, with assistance from international and local consultants, and in partnership with the IDA and the SDC. The main project components (roads, markets, ghats) have been selected following an intensive process involving beneficiary participation, subject to possible essential changes in future; for smaller components (rural structures etc.) selection process will start following credit approval. Out of the list of FRB roads selected for improvement under the project, five roads in Greater Dhaka Area (41 hcm) have already been tendered under retroactive financing (para. 3.21) and work started in January 1996. Supervision consultants for this part of the work have also been appointed following IDA procedures. 2.45 Engineering designs of FRB roads, markets and ghats proposed for implementation in 1996/97 (first year) have been completed, and contracts for most first year works, particularly for FRB roads, have already been awarded. Further preparatory work, including preparation of the engineering designs and bidding documents for second year (1997-98) FRB roads, markets and ghats, is in an advanced stage and would be completed by end of January 1997. LGED has appointed DSM Consultants in November 1996, following IDA guidelines. LGED has already appointed Project Director and other key staff of the Project Implementation Office (PIO). Work on designing markets with community iilputs is in progress with assistance of preparation consultants, and has been completed for about eighteen markets. Process of selecting NGOs for further NMT component has been started and will be completed soon after IDA credit approval. The Land Acquisition Action Plan (para. 3.28), and the Sector Environmental Assessment (para. 3.29) for the related civil works have been prepared in accordance with IDA guidelines and have been agreed during negotiations. 2.46 Considerable preparation for the component of SRR component has been completed including the agreement on participatory procedures in consultation with the local bodies, UPs, TDCC and the local communities. The actual physical work on this component will start only after the project approval, since the local bodies who are required to put up initial deposit to signal their participation in this component, need confirmation on project funding from IDA. The low-cost engineering design for all sizes of structures have already been developed under RRMIMP-1 and it will take only about two days for LGED field engineers to finalize the design after site selection is done by local communities. About 1200 similar structures have already been constructed under RRMIMP-1, and the experience shows that this component would move expeditiously. The UP chairpersons have shown enthusiastic support for this component and have indicated that if each UP goes for two structures, the proposed 6,000 structures would be fully committed early in the project cycle. Since these are several separate contracts to be executed under the supervision of LGED Thana Engineers, contracts in the different locations can move simultaneously. The procurement and account-keeping arrangements acceptable to IDA for small structures have already been established under RRMIMP-1 and would be followed under the proposed project. To increase public awareness of this nationwide component and to encourage local community to prepare for active participation in it, the LGED has already launched public campaign through the media and other channels. Given the innovative features introduced on participatory process for the structure's site selection and the requirement of an initial deposit by UPs, it is likely that the physical progress of this component may be slow during the first year, but should gain momentum in the subsequent years.
 36 3. PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION A. AN OVERVIEW OF THE PARTICIPATORY PROCESS 3.1 The project is considered by IDA as a "flagship" operation in using participatory approach in view of its emphasis on using borrower and beneficiary participation in the selection, design and implementation of the project. The participatory approach was emphasized right from the start of project preparation by organizing several participatory meetings with 'users', rural communities, beneficiaries, local government and the related government and non-government organizations. Locations of main project components (roads, river jetties, markets), have been selected using active involvement of beneficiaries. Rural structures (SRR costing more than 35% of the project costs), will be selected using specially designed participatory processes agreed during negotiations (see Annex 2.1). The local bodies (UPs) will put 10-20% (para.2.42) of the structure costs up-front to signal their financial stake. Actual selection of the structures will be done through a participatory process involving two stages: (i) selection by UP residents through group meetings for discussing alternatives using user-inputs techniques (such as, map-making etc.), most likely with assistance of LGED's community organizers and the projects' participation facilitators (which assistance may not be available in all cases); and (ii) voting by UP council on the proposed sites (see para. 2.17). Road designs take into account user preferences, particularly, concerns of NMT operators who are major users. In the case of growth center markets, the design and layout of facilities is being done in full day meetings with poor vendors and others who would be the main users of these market facilities; they will also be given a key role in managing the markets (regarding level of user charges, auctioning of market lease, maintenance arrangements and funding), through market committees of users, reporting every six months to an "assembly" of market users, with special emphasis on information sharing. Similarly, country boat operators and other user groups will be actively involved in Ghat selection, design and management. For road components, user committees will be set up to give feed back on design and quality of on-going works. LGED will also initiate pilot programs in at least two districts to try out new ways for greater community involvement in road maintenance. Many of the participatory processes used are based on lessons learned from different pilot programs undertaken in Bangladesh in which LGED has been involved. 3.2 To ensure the participatory process to be more transparent and well implemented, the project would finance 17 positions of local specialists in community participation (sociologists or equivalent) and one expatriate expert with local experience; of these one community specialist will be placed in each project district, and three community specialists (supervisors) will be assigned to advise and assist the Project Director and LGED headquarters. Annex 2.1) include appointment by LGED of 17 qualified community specialists before March 31, 1997: eight of them have been appointed, as an advance measure agreed during negotiations.  46 4. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION & RISKS A. PROJECT BENEFITS AND ECONOMIC RETURN Nature of project benefits 4.1 The project would benefit the project area through improvement in access and more efficient marketing, and would also bring several other socio-economic benefits which are difficult to quantify. The following discusses the general nature of benefits based on previous impact studies, and also presents a partial economic return analysis of the proposed project based on easily quantifiable benefits. 4.2 The critical importance of improving the condition of rural roads and markets in Bangladesh as a way to improve rural income and reduce poverty has been recognized in the country's development strategy. The Rural Infrastructure Strategy study carried out by the IDA in collaboration with GOB/LGED confirms that much of the rural road system, and most of the important markets, remain in poor condition; it also found that investment on improving these facilities is essential to develop rural economy and to reduce rural poverty, and recommends a larger investment program than undertaken in the past decade. Recent IDA/GOB study on agricultural strategy also underlines the need for improving rural infrastructure in support of agricultural diversification and growth, and IDA's Country Assistance Strategy emphasizes rural transport development in view of its impact on agriculture, rural economic growth, employment and poverty alleviation. 4.3 There is evidence to demonstrate the strong relationship between socio-economic well-being and rural infrastructure supply, in the light of various studies in Bangladesh. Studies further show that these investments benefit the rural poor more: the functionally landless and small farmers gained a larger share of the increase from crops, wages, and livestock and fisheries, and there was a higher proportion of employment of women. Socio-economic monitoring and evaluation studies under different LGED RDP projects show that improvement of FRBs produces a significant increase in non- motorized and motorized transport services, a shift to more efficient transport modes, lower transport costs for goods and passengers, a reduction in the dependence on travel by foot and head-porterage for carrying of goods, and a substantial increase in traffic volumes, with overall improved access to goods and to social services. The same studies show that the improvement of rural market facilities, combined with FRB improvements, leads to increases in throughput of goods, number of market visitors, market turnover and market lease value, to reduced spoilage of goods, with the markets developing into more efficient and hygienic trading centers for the poor farmers and vendors who are their main users. More specifically, post appraisal of completed project components under the ongoing RRMIMP-1 (RDP-7) show that traffic volumes in ton-km and passenger-km increased over 70% in cargo and over 172 % in passenger traffic on the improved roads in the first year following development, that bus services started for the first time on these roads which brought major benefits to local people, and that partial quantified benefits from the project showed about 22% (range 14 - 45%) Economic Rate of Return (ERR) from road investments and from market investments. Further, estimates based on surveys of employment created under the completed rural infrastructure components show, that on completion in 1997, these components, costing about US$64 million equivalent, would have created: about 18,000 person-years of direct employment through labor-based construction activities, and indirect employment at a rate of about 6000 person-years per year (in maintenance about 1000, and the rest in rickshaw-van and other transport operations, in markets, new road-side shops etc.) which would be continued during the project life.
 47 4.4 The Project Area: The Northwest Region remains economically and socially disadvantaged - agricultural wage labor rates, GDP per capita, and male and female adult literacy rates are all below the national average. Communications between the Northwest Region and the rest of the country will be improved with the completion of the Jamuna Multi-Purpose Bridge; further development of the road and market network will allow the area to exploit the economic opportunities that this will provide. The rural Greater Dhaka Districts (except one) did not benefit from any RDPs, so far, and have severe deficiencies in its rural transport and market infrastructure to serve its fast-growing high-price horticultural crops which need timely transport and marketing; this area has higher population density and higher traffic (NMT-dominated) than the North-West Region. Even after the completion of the proposed project, both these areas would still meet only about 50-60% of the estimated current requirements in infrastructure improvements. Economic Return Analysis 4.5 The project's Economic Rate of Return (ERR) has been estimated based on quantifiable benefits with reference to three main components: FRB road improvements, growth-center markets, and Structures on Rural Roads (SRRs), as summarized below; a composite ERR for the project was then estimated based on these three components. 4.6 FRB road improvements: The detailed analysis of economic costs and benefits of improvement and upgrading of FRB roads, is given in PID-15. The analysis is at 1995 prices. The costs in the economic analysis comprise the estimated investment in road improvement and upgrading and construction of structures, land acquisition and tree plantation, routine and periodic maintenance over the predicted 15 year life of the roads, and 7% of construction costs as an allowance for design and supervision. Taxes, duties and contingencies are excluded. Costs of imported goods are taken at border prices (cif prices), and the local costs are adjusted to border prices using a general conversion factor of 0.9. Similar adjustments are also made for the value of benefits. The economic benefits accrue to savings in vehicle operating costs (VOC). For vehicles, VOC savings are estimated from input prices and cross-checked and verified against actual tariff charges in the rural transport market. For non-motorized means of transport VOC savings are based on actual differentials in charges between existing poor and improved roads, as they substantially reflect the cost variations due to greater exertion and energy levels (food as fuel) needed for rougher roads, in the highly competitive markets for these services. A good body of comparative data on these charges has been collected in Bangladesh from past studies under ongoing projects and through surveys for the proposed project which provide a consistent pattern of cost differences for different road conditions and vehicle types. Impact studies on completed projects (see para. 1.49 and Annex 1.4) also show a consistent pattern of changes in vehicle types as roads are improved, for example from walking to bicycles and buses, from bullock carts to rickshaw vans and small trucks, etc. which provide reliable estimates of traffic pattern and growth. Transport cost differences are estimated based on changes in modal-mix assumed based on such information. Bench-mark traffic surveys have been made for all 69 roads selected for the project. 4.7 Traffic growth has been estimated as follows: annual 8% for normal growth (about 1.5 times the expected economic growth rate, based on available country-wide estimates); a generated traffic due to road improvement using a price elasticity of demand for goods and passenger transport of -1 with reference to transport cost reductions, and for diverted traffic based on the actual potential as assessed through surveys as this varies from case to case. Overall , the traffic projected is very conservative compared to actual growth recorded in the case of similar road improvements completed under the IDA-SDC-KfW -supported RRMIMP-1, and under the GTZ - supported RDP-14, where traffic increased steeply (motor vehicles and NMT vehicles by 160% and 146% respectively; passenger traffic volume in passenger-kms by over 172% mainly because of starting of bus services, and cargo ton-kms
 48 by 70%) the pre-development level within about a year after road development; this shows that the dynamism of economic and traffic growth is higher than conventionally assumed growth rates, and that even as a road is improved (preceded by a long process of preparation and public awareness) change begins to take place without much time-lags. The traffic assumptions made in this study lead to an overall traffic growth of the following order for a typical road: total traffic increase (in ton-kmn and passenger-kin) after three years after work completion (giving time for full generated traffic and traffic diversion to come about) of about 55% in passenger and 104% in goods, the latter consisting of about 26% normal growth in three years (at cumulative annual rate of 8%), 37% generated traffic (total one- time growth spread over three years) and 41 % diverted traffic (total one-time growth); after the three years, total traffic is assumed to increase at the normal growth rate of 8%. Compared to the post- appraisal traffic growth rates noted above, these projections are very conservative, particularly for the passenger traffic. The transport cost differences are estimated using changed modal mixes and costs, following development, as discussed earlier, taking into account the characteristics of each road. Full transport cost savings are included as project benefits for normal traffic growth, and only 50% savings for generated and diverted traffic as well. 4.8 The economic rate of return on the investment in FRB improvement and upgrading, based on the transport cost savings, is estimated as 30.4%. The flow of costs and benefits for a sample project road, and other details of the analysis are presented in PID-15. 4.9 SRRs: The main economic significance of SRR investment is that an investment of about US$8,000 on an SRR will convert about 1.75 km of existing rural road (costing about US$70,000) from a seasonal to all-season road. The economic analysis of the Structures on Rural Roads (SRR) component (see PID-16) is based on a 'typical investment scheme to construct small structures on a length of Rural Road in order to span two gaps and provide a continuous road alignment. The costs in the analysis include the investment in the construction of the structures and the ancillary earthworks, routine and periodic maintenance of the road and the structures over the predicted 15 year life, and 7% of construction costs as an allowance for design and supervision. The benefits from the investment have been derived based on field surveys of a sample of Rural Roads with and without gaps. These show that the major benefit from providing continuous alignments is to eliminate the delays that occur, particularly in the wet season, in crossing gaps or diverting to other, longer routes to avoid the gaps. The spanning of the gaps will stimulate the growth of wheeled traffic and generate passenger and goods movement on the road. The benefits are estimated as the time savings to normal and generated traffic - pedestrians, passengers and vehicles - from eliminating the delays caused by gaps plus the savings in ferry charges - 'informal' ferry services operate across some gaps during the wet season. The base case economic rate of return for the SRR component, based on a 'typical' scheme is 30.2%. The flow of costs and benefits for a typical SRR scheme is presented in PID-16. Nearly 30% of the benefits accrue to the poorest beneficiaries, the pedestrians who continue to travel on foot after the structures have been constructed because the cannot afford to use other means of transport. The component will benefit them in terms of better access to work, to markets and to social services. 4.10 The SRR component will comprise a large number of small investment schemes (each structure (usually a culvert) costing about US$8,000 equivalent, with significant variability in the structures required and the traffic volumes between individual schemes. Tests have therefore been carried out to analyze the sensitivity of the rate of return to these variables. If the size of the structures required is larger than in the typical scheme, costs will increase. A cost increase of 20% reduces the rate of return to 25%, and a cost increase of 50% reduces it to 19%. Costs must increase by over 120% to bring the rate of return down to 12 %. If traffic volume is less than in the typical scheme, benefits will decrease. A decrease of 20% in traffic volume reduces the rate of return to 24%. A traffic volume 45% of that on the 'typical' scheme is sufficient to give an economic rate of return of 12%. The economic justification for the SRR component is therefore very robust.
 49 4.11 Growth Centre Markets: Many Growth Centre markets (public facilities for trading produce and goods with basic facilities for cleanliness, drainage and paved areas partly under roof, each costing about US$60,000 a piece) will be improved at the same time that the FRBs that serve them are improved and upgraded; in some cases roads are already improved. It is therefore difficult to isolate the respective contributions of the market investment and the road improvements. One benefit that is specific to the market improvements is the reduction in spoilage of marketed produce. Because the improved market is clean, and the produce is protected from the elements and sold more quickly, spoilage losses for items such as rice, fish, meat, eggs, milk and vegetables are reduced. The economic analysis for market improvement (PID-17) is therefore based on the benefits from reduced spoilage - this can be seen as a proxy for the increased profitability to sellers of produce directly due to the market improvements. The costs included in the analysis are the investment in the improved facilities, the routine and periodic maintenance over the assumed 15 year life of the market and 7% of construction costs as an allowance for design and supervision. The RRMIMP SEM&E studies show that market improvements reduce spoilage losses by about 3 % of the value of the vulnerable produce. Based on the characteristics of, and the volumes of goods sold in, the Growth Centre markets proposed for improvement, a spoilage savings of 3% will generate an economic rate of return for the project markets of 20.2%. The return is higher for large markets (25%) and lower for small markets (14%). The flow of costs and benefits for a medium-sized market is presented in PID-17. These rates of return are based on partial benefits since: (a) there are other economic benefits to market users, particularly the regular traders, from the much more hygienic conditions in the improved markets; (the usually dirty and stinking market areas where the poor vendors trade would turn into clean dry areas, garbage giving place to clean bio-gas in some cases where small low-cost pilot facilities will be installed for the purpose); moreover, new permanent private shops open up around the public markets while existing shops expand, land values and rents increase). (b) the integration of investments in improvement of markets, roads and ghats will together stimulate increased trading and economic activity at the markets. It is reasonable to argue that a proportion of these benefits is attributable to the market investment. 4.12 Seen as a joint investment with roads (with market investment being about 10% of the investment on a typical 7 km road improvement, the latter producing about 30% ERR), the investment has high ERR even if market benefits are excluded. Testing of the sensitivity of the economic rate of return to the key assumptions made in the SRR analysis shows that if the costs are 20% higher than estimated the rate of return is 17%. If the spoilage savings is only 2.4% rather than the 3.0% predicted, the rate of return is 16%. A spoilage savings of 2% is sufficient to give an economic return rate of 12%. 4.13 The composite rate of return for the three components for which economic analysis has been carried out ( weighted average) is 29.5%. Table 4.1 shows that the three components for which economic analysis has been carried out represent 71 % of the total financial cost of the project. The economic costs included in the analysis amount to 75.5% of the total economic cost of the project. The components that have not been analyzed will also generate economic benefits. The construction of 'Structures on Other FRB' can be expected to have similar impacts to the SRRs. The road safety measures will reduce losses due to accidental injury and death. Periodic maintenance of roads is known to be economically efficient, and the ghat improvements will generate benefits through reduced spoilage and increased safety. The pilot component to improve NMT will ultimately lead to more efficient provision of rural transport services, and the technical assistance will increase the efficiency
 50 of LGED as a rural infrastructure provider. Further, as noted above, there are additional, unquantified economic benefits from the three components that have been analyzed. While transport cost savings are the mechanism through which many of the economic impacts are generated, given that transport and trading permeates so many aspects of rural life in Bangladesh the provision of improved access will generate other effects such as new income-generation opportunities, faster diffusion of agricultural technologies and increased utilization of health and educational services. The critical importance of improving the condition of rural roads and markets in Bangladesh as a way to improve rural income and reduce poverty has been recognized in the country's development strategy. The project focuses on rural areas where the incidence of poverty is more widespread (see para. 2); its special focus is on Northwest region, which is the poorest region in the country. Choice of project facilities has given priority to areas where people suffer from inadequate access and poor market facilities. Overall, the proportion of the poor among project beneficiaries will be significantly larger than their proportion in total population (see para. 3). Improvement of markets will provide better and more healthy facilities for poor market vendors. The use of labor-intensive methods for civil works will create over 20,000 person-years of employment in construction, and more than 2,000 person-years of employment annually in maintenance which will continue beyond the project period; based on RRMIMP-1 completion studies, other new employment as transport operators (mainly NMT), vehicle repairs and service, and small trading and shop-keeping could exceed 10,000 persons annually. Most of the beneficiaries from increased employment will be the landless poor, destitute women, and under- employed small farmers. Most works would be done through labor-intensive methods, using appropriate small equipment, to maximize employment impact. Many construction works, and all routine maintenance works, will be targeted at the landless and at disadvantaged women, particularly through the use of labor contracting societies under which poor workers organize themselves as small contractors thus earning more than the usual wage. B. PROJECT RISKS 4.18 There are no major risks in proceeding with the project. Project risks have been minimized by special design features and measures taken or built into project preparation and implementation. The project concept has already been tested successfully through the ongoing RRMIMP-1. The project has been carefully designed to achieve effective implementation, and many of its features such as definition of the PIO management structure, incremental staffing, tasks of the DSM consultants, and monitoring procedures, are modeled on the ongoing project experience with necessary improvements based on lessons learnt. LGED has demonstrated its capability to implement projects efficiently and coordinate effectively with donors, and the project will further strengthen its management capacity. To sustain the flow of benefits from project investments, Government funds are available for FRB maintenance, and LGED has already established the basis of a maintenance management system, which will be further supported through the project components. 4.19 The following assesses potential project risks, and measures adopted to minimize them: the risks discussed relate to: (a) possible constraints in contractor capacity to implement the project which is much larger than the ongoing project and is to be implemented in a shorter period; (b) possible constraints in LGED's implementation capacity for the larger project; (c) delays in land acquisition, (d) the large national component on rural structures which was not in the first project; (e) possible failure of the participatory processes being tried out for the first time on such large scale; and (f) inadequate maintenance funding and arrangements.
 52 (a) The project size and contractor capacity 4.20 Reference is invited to Annex 3.3 which presents a full analysis of project size increase compared to the ongoing first project, and assesses the capacity of contractors and LGED to implement such a larger project. The proposed project is about 50% larger than the ongoing project comparing levels of total physical output; considering also its shorter implementation period of five years, the annual output level is about 107% more; if a six-year implementation period is considered, the annual output is about 72% higher. Against this, the project area is about 75 % larger (14 districts versus 8), which means that there is also about 75% increase in contractor capacity as the small size contractors to do feeder road works and markets and river ghats are generally available in all districts, their operations being generally limited by logistical problems to one or two districts; the project would provide training and other support , including equipment on lease, to enhance the quality and capacity of these contractors; in fact, recent bidding under retroactive financing for 45 km of roads (about 11 contracts) under the new project in the new project districts (greater Dhaka) has already shown an average qualified bidders per contract. 4.21 Thus, about 75% capacity increase can be explained from the increased project area with its own contracting capacity. The remaining extra capacity (of about 32%) is expected from the fact that the new project is not a pilot project and is built on lessons already learnt from the first project in trying out various specifications, standards and procedures. LGED have also become more experienced; the new project has also many measures to increase contractor efficiency and capacity (larger size contracts of average 4-6 km, with 2-year contracts, provision of mobilization advances for buying own equipment, as against one-year contracts of 2-3 km without mobilization advance under the first project; higher standards in prequalifying contractors, more training etc.); it also will give about 100 km of the roads to a new category of medium size contractors (for 10 km, US $ 1 m value contracts) who currently work on the main roads projects under RHD, who will infuse new capacity to the feeder road sector). In addition, 45 km FRB improvements have already started under retroactive financing before project approval. Many initial delays which affected the first project would be avoided by making the appointment of supervision consultants and bidding for first year works a condition before Board presentation. The second project is much better prepared and its implementation in all aspects would be more efficient. No significant risk in contractor capacity is therefore expected. 4.22 A sensitivity analysis shows that if a 6-year implementation period is used instead of 5 years, the extra output and capacity needed is only 72% above the first project, which can be fully met from the capacity gain due to area expansion; the factors of efficiency increase noted above will, in this case, create a slack in capacity and give a large extra cushion. Therefore, if implementation is found lagging, a decision can be made at mid-term review to extend the implementation period by one year or to restructure the project with more allocation for fast moving components. 4.23 As regards the national components, the SRR components would be done mainly through a different category of very small labor contractors (contracts of about $8000 each), for which there is no shortage (see para. below on SRR). The NMT component would be implemented almost entirely through experienced local NGOs with minimal supervision from LGED. (b) LGED capacity to implement the project 4.24 LGED capacity to implement the project as noted has expanded very much under various management improvement measures, and its institutional capacity would be further enhanced through the project and through other donor support. LGED has become a much more experienced body over the past decade (now implementing about US$1 billion worth of projects portfolio mostly funded by foreign agencies) and is rated a successful and dynamic agency; (see para. 1.42). In addition, the
 53 project would provide incremental staff in the project areas, will have a larger PIO with deputy director for the new project districts as they need special attention and another Deputy Director to look after the SRR components through participatory specialists to be recruited, and additional senior staff for project monitoring and other functions (see para. 3.6), it will also have a large DSM consultants support appropriate for the larger size project. A new feature would be technical audit by a private sector firm, which will carry out regular six-monthly inspection of work verification and technical quality as an additional control and monitoring tool to ensure efficient and timely project implementation. All these measures would minimize any possible risk about LGED's capacity to manage the project. (c) Delays in land acquisition 4.25 Procedure for acquisition of land in accordance with OD 4.30 will be more rigorous than on the RRMIMP-1 in respect of compensating all affected persons at full market value of losses, and paying compensation prior to commencement of construction works on the land to be acquired. The risk is that land acquisition will take longer than planned so that implementation of FRB improvement and upgrading works is delayed. This risk has been reduced by the following factors: Most works are on existing alignments, and only marginal additional land needs to be acquired; LGED has experience in land acquisition in the first project though compensation in that project was not insisted to be paid before start of works (the typical land acquisition is for marginal addition to road width on existing roads from land -owners alongside roads, who in many cases are willing to give land free for road improvement since improved road will give them much better access to markets and health ,school and other facilities, and will also enhance value of their remaining land); LGED has a decentralized field office network which would help them to implement and monitor land acquisition work in coordination with the various land-related agencies and local affected persons and UPs; LGED land acquisition capacity will be reinforced with incremental staffing in each District and DSM consultant inputs; and, a realistic action plan for land acquisition has been agreed. (d) Large National SRR component 4.26 It is true that this is the first time a nationwide component with such participatory process is being designed. However, risks of its failure are minimized by many factors. As noted (see para. 2.17) there is general enthusiasm among UPs, based on preliminary interviews, to go for this component, as it meets a critical local need, with only 10-20% contribution of UP funds. The 6000 structures under the project could be absorbed by 1-2 structures in each UP, or more likely with more in some UPs since a competitive system has been designed for eligibility. Though the initial selection process may be delayed, their construction period is only about 2 months each. Contractor capacity already exists as demonstrated by another ongoing nationwide structures project funded by USAID; and the proposed project's efforts to involve labor-contracting societies will further enhance capacity. LGED has already helped build about 1200 such rural structures with good success under the first project (though selection was not participatory), and this has already established a good supervisory and financial control system. The work will be supervised by LGED's Thana engineers who operate in all Thanas; DSM engineers will also supervise the work on a selective basis. An experienced Deputy Director will coordinate and provide overall supervision for the PIO. Even though UPs have a major voice in selection and implementation, contracts will be awarded through TDCC Tender Committees (which has LGED and UP representation) under IDA procurement procedures, as done for the first project, and project accounts will be maintained as under the first project; therefore, there is no risk of lack of financial control; private financial auditors and "technical performance" auditors (new feature) would further keep close watch through sample checks of quality and financial aspects with special emphasis on this component.
