Introduction Local Government is an important partner in the RRMIMP-2 for several reasons: 1. Investment in rural infrastructure development continues to be a priority in Bangladesh. Several Rural Development Projects (RDPs) such as the RRMIMP-2 provide this rural infrastructure. This will increase the future requirements for maintenance for which responsibility lies to a great extend with Local Government. 2. In crder to make sure that the real needs of the rural population are addressed it is important to associate Local Government and the local population from the planning stage on. Responsible management and maintenance of the rural infrastructure will improve when Local Government and the population are involved early on in the process of provision of the infrastructure. Their participation in planning and monitoring is therefore a necessary aspect of the project. Institutional strengthening will improve the capacity of local governments to take up these tasks. 3. The financing of infrastructure maintenance and investments is another aspect of the Local Governments' responsibilities. The mobilisation of local resources, both to contribute to the cost of infrastructure investment, and to finance the maintenance of certain types of rural infrastructure, is also important in ensuring that infrastructure investment schemes meet local priorities, in developing a sense of local ownership of the improved infrastructure, and in achieving sustainability of the infrastructure investment. Finding ways to increase local resources will be necessary if the local governments are to take up their responsibilities. 2. Evolution of Local Government in Bangladesh Local Government exists in the sub-continent since ancient times. In the Rig Vedas, the oldest Hindu religious writings, dating from approximately 1200 B.C., forms of village self-government are mentioned. Panchayets (village councils) seem to have existed since very early times even if their functions, power and their place in the system of self-government vary considerably. Under the early British rule a policy of curbing the powers of indigenous local institutions was adopted, but by the end of the 19th century the need for responsible local government was recognised and introduced by passing the "Local Self-Government Act of 1885". The "Bengal Village Self- Government Act of 1919" introduced more representative local government bodies. The Union Boards comprised two-thirds of elected members and one-third nominated, they covered 10 to 12 square miles and a population of about 6,000 to 8,000 people. At the higher up level Local Board members were chosen by open election and finally at the upper local government level, District Boards were for two- thirds elected and one-third nominated.
 59 Annex 1.1 Page 2 of 18 After the partition of India in 1947, the Government of Pakistan retained the system of Union and District Boards - the intermediate local boards had slowly died out - , this situation persisted until 1959. The military junta which staged a coup d'etat in 1958 introduced an authoritarian government and promulgated the "Basic Democracies Order". In contrast with earlier local government enactments, this order was a central legislation having jurisdiction over the whole of Pakistan. The local government system consisted of four tiers in rural areas: Union Councils, Thana Councils, District Councils and Divisional Councils. One-third of the Union Councils were nominated but in the three higher up Councils the official nominees could represent up to 50 percent of the membership. In 1972 soon after the emergence of Bangladesh all local bodies except the Divisional Council were dissolved and administrators appointed to take over their functions. The Divisional Council was later abolished. In 1976 the new government promulgated a Local Government Ordinance with three tiers: Union Parishad, Thana Parishad and Zila Parishad. After Ershad took power in 1982, local govermnent was reorganised with the Thana as focal point of administration. Responsibility for all developmental activities at the local level was transferred to the Thana Parishads, renamed Upazila Parishads. The central government retained direct responsibility for all major development activities. After the political upheavals of 1990, the new democratic government which came to power in 1991 abolished the Upazila Parishads. Further legislation created a two tier local government with Union Parishads and District Parishads. At the thana level a Thana Development Co-ordination Committee was created and at the village level a Village Development Committee. 3. The Actual Situation of the Union Parishads (UPs) The Union Parishad is an elected representative body. Its functions have been defined in the Local Government (Union Parishad) (Amendment) Act, 1993, which lists about 38 functions, the most important of these concern: * maintenance of security; * adoption and implementation of development schemes; * promotion of family planning; * development and use of local resources; * protection and maintenance of public property such as roads, bridges, canals, embankments, ghats, markets, telephone and electricity lines; * registration of births, deaths, blind people, beggars and destitutes; * conducting of census of all kinds; * etc. In addition the Union Parishad is also charged with the planning function, the UP is required to prepare Five-Year and Annual development Plans. Unfortunately most UPs do not have the required staff to carry out this activity. The structure and staffing of Union Parishads are detailed in Attachment 1. In the area of infrastructure the relevant responsibilities of Union Parishads can be summarised as follows:

The key weaknesses in the new system are of institutional and of financial nature (a) institutional: * Unions are at very low level - 4,450 Unions, average area 30sq.km., average population 25,000. * Union Parishads have very limited staff capacity or capability, and much of the work must be done by the elected members - yet at the same time progressively increasing demands are placed on the Union Parishads. Recommendations for Improving Management and Cost Recovery. (see also para. 1.35 in SAR) As in other countries, markets are potentially an important source of income for the development budget of local government. But as indicated above, UPs get only part of the income (40%) from the smaller markets and only a fixed lump sum (Tk. 20.000) from the markets with a lease above Tk. 50,000, the main income from the markets goes thus to central and thana level government. This regulation does not create enough of an incentive to motivate UPs to develop their markets into dynamic income generating operations. This is probably one of the main reasons for the ineffectiveness of the Union Market Management Committees. Another reason for their ineffectiveness is probably the fact that members of this committee are not rewarded for the work they do in this commission. A number of measures could be taken to increase the part of the income going to the UPs in order to motivate them into developing the markets, such as: increasing the limit of Tk. 50,000 to Tk. 100,000 or Tk. 200,000 and decreasing the part of central government. But it could also be argued that well functioning markets are of prime importance for the country and that therefore important incentives must be given to UPs to efficiently manage and develop their markets. This could be done by letting them keep all the income generated by the markets and even by providing them with matching grants to increase proportionally the income generated by the markets. These measures would provide powerful incentives to UPs to develop these markets and would at the same time provide the UPs with an important source of revenues. The argument that the income of markets must be distributed to all unions, also to those that do not have important markets, should be put in the context of the global resources of the UPs - most of the income of UPs comes from central government anyway and it is very well possible to compensate UPs that do not have an important market, without taking income away from UPs that do have an efficient income generating market. Other measures to improve revenue from markets would be to increase the tolls paid by the market vendors. Tolls (unit rates per bag, basket or quantity of produce sold) are now the same for all markets in each district and are fixed by the districts authorities without differentiating between improved and non-improved markets. Market revenue after development goes up through increased turn-over of trading even with same unit rate. GOB does not favour unit tariff increase, as this would discourage the poor vendors to use the unhygienic road side markets thus losing many social benefits. There are also complaints that the leaseholders often charge more than the official tariffs from the vendors. The higher toll would translate into higher revenues for the UPs only if the leasing system is fully competitive, as mentioned above this is not the case and certain measures could be taken to improve the situation such as the use of more transparent procedures and wide based competition to reduce collusion in market leasing, with better information sharing arrangements, publicity arrangements, tendering done by district level agencies and appropriate user participation under agreed guidelines. Therefore it is recommended for the project to focus on developing the management capability of market/ghat committees for operation and maintenance. The 'information sharing' approach will contribute to this but the project will also include: - definition of procedures for cleaning and maintenance, removing responsibility from the leaseholder;

However, specific attention will be given to market leases as a source of funds for local revenue generation. There are two aspects: i) the present allocation of market lease revenue gives only limited incentive to UPs to generate the maximum funds from their markets and to develop those markets. The present re-distributive mechanism to allocate some of the revenue from a large market in a particular Union to other Unions in the Thana through the TDCC, is excessive (in simple terms for markets with a lease revenue of more than Taka 50,000, that part of the lease revenue which is retained at local level is allocated to the TDCC rather than the UP); ii) at present the potential value of market leasing is not realised, and many of the leaseholders make large profits - it is variously estimated that the total income from a market is 3-11 times, and 5 times, the lease value. This is a complex socio-political issue in the context of rural Bangladesh (one large NGO, BRAC, has become involved in the leasing of markets but recognises that it is fraught with difficulties). However practical possibilities have been identified: - leasing by users' collectives; * increasing the visibility and transparency of the lease bidding process. * monitoring of market toll revenue as a basis for assessing lease bid values. The project includes a number of up-front actions as an interim measure before Board presentation of the project, and further follow-up measures within about 18 months after Board presentation in the light of further studies (funded under the project). (a) The up front actions related to market/ghat leasing and management are given in para. 7.1 of this annex. (b) In addition to the above interim measures, a study on improving revenue mobilisation by UP's including better systems for ghats and markets management and leasing should be completed by about December 1997 (a year after IDA Board date), and its recommendations reviewed and implemented in consultation with IDA/SDC before about June 1998. The study should examine, among other things, (i) the case for and feasibility of increasing unit toll rates of markets after they are developed, and (ii) suitable procedures for management of ghats with user participation, preferably on the lines of the UMMCs.

Introduction LGED originated from a small cell in the Local Government Division (LGD) during the late 1970s. This led to the formation of the Works Programme Wing in 1982, and of the Local Government Engineering Bureau in 1984, which was upgraded to a Department in 1992. LGED's task load has increased at a very rapid rate during this period of growth. Its tasks have been widened and it now implements a large portfolio of donor-supported and GOB financed programs. Its responsibilities include construction and maintenance of FRBs and rural roads, drainage structures and mnarkets; small- scale water resources schemes; construction of schools and cyclone shelters; food-aided rural infrastructure programs; provision of technical supervision and advice to local government bodies; and infrastructure works with pourashavas (secondary towns). Annex 1.4 gives more information about road and market related rural infrastructure development projects being executed by LGED. Most of the donor-financed infrastructure projects implemented by LGED include institutional development activities. In addition: * sThe Institutional Support Project (ISP) of the SIDA/NORAD financed Rural Employment Support Program (RESP) provides long-term institutional support to LGED through three units - the Training Unit (TU), the Technical Design and Management Unit (TDMU) and the Physical Planning and Management Unit (PPMU). The third phase of ISP was appraised in September 1995 and the report finalised in December 1995. * In parallel with the RDP-18 project, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) is financing three technical assistance components - Training, Maintenance Management, and the Management Capability Strengthening Project (MANCAPS). The aim of the first phase of MANCAPS is to carry out an institutional and management analysis of LGED, and make recommendations for its future management development, focusing on four issues -institutional management, institutional organisation, financial management and engineering management. MANCAPS has prepared a draft action plan for the management strengthening of LGED'. The MANCAPS report concludes that: * LGED is effective and successful in the implementation of the tasks assigned. * Its strengths lie in teamn work, field orientation, dynamic leadership, hard work, informal decision making, and emphasis on training and management of its external relations. * LGED is now reaching maturity and entering a new phase in its development, where it is important to consolidate and even further strengthen the organisation. Draft Action Plan - Directions in Management Development of LGED. MANCAPS, March 1995.
 77 Annex 1.2 Page 2 of 5 * LGED should become the most efficient delivery channel for rural and semi-urban infrastructure development. * With tihe rapid increase in work-load most LGED personnel are heavily loaded, and this has led to a number of ad-hoc organisational arrangements. The current organisation has large management spans, matrix organisational structure, and complex inter-action with ISP. The MANCAPS study therefore recommends: * A comprehensive re-organisation of LGED to reduce the management span, including the introduction of a 'circle' level of management between the 64 Districts and headquarters. * The formation of seven departments at headquarters each headed by a Superintending Engineer, and the creation of a second Additional Chief Engineer post. * The integration of ISP functions into the established LGED structure including the creation of an LGED Design Cell to prepare manuals, specifications and design standards and to provide technical supervision and co-ordination of the work of design consultants. * The strengthening of the planning, and management information systems (MIS) functions including monitoring and evaluation (M&E), and the preparation of a MIS master plan. The existing LGED organisation structure and the organisation chart proposed by MANCAPS are attached (Attachments 1 and 2). The IDA/SDC appraisal mission agreed with many of the recommendations of MANCAPS and, in order to contribute to the management strengthening of LGED a number of them will be implemented and financed under the project. The RRMIMP-2 will finance 7 positions as incremental staff: - The position of a second Additional Chief Engineer in charge of Design, Planning, and Monitoring and Evaluation (this position is referred to in the organisation chart as Additional Chief Engineer - 1) * The position of Superintending Engineer (Design, Quality control and Research and Development) to head the Design Cell. under the second Additional Chief Engineer. * Two Assistant Engineer positions (Roads and Structures) in the Design Cell. * The positions of a Transport Economist and a Monitoring & Evaluation expert in the Monitoring and Evaluation cell under the second Additional Chief Engineer * The position of a Sociologist (Participation and Land Acquisition) in the Planning Cell under the second Additional Chief Engineer. This will contribute to institutionalising functions now taken up on a temporary basis under Technical Assistance provided by the ISP. The IFPRI Study A major study on the impact of rural infrastructure development in Bangladesh, carried out by the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) with the Bangladesh Institute of Development Studies (BIDS) was published in 19901. This study surveyed 129 villages which were classified as "developed" and "undeveloped" based on an infrastructure index which considered access to transport, markets, schools, banks, modem inputs, electricity, and local administrative offices. From this sample 16 villages, seven "developed" and nine "undeveloped", were selected and detailed household surveys conducted. The study found that, comparing the two categories, the villages with "developed" infrastructure were significantly better off in a number of areas: * Farmgate prices of rice were 7 % higher. -- Fertilizer prices were 14% lower and fertilizer utilization was 92% higher. 105% more land was irrigated and 71% more sown with HYV seeds. Household income was 8% higher. *; The wage rate was 12% higher. There were particular benefits for the poor - wage income of landless laborers was 36% higher, and the proportion of female workers was 135% higher. 2. Impact of FRB Road Improvements There is increasing emphasis on socio-economic monitoring and evaluation (SEM&E) activities in the Rural Development Projects implemented by LGED. Through the SEM&E activities of different projects, a data-base of time-series information on the effect of FRB improvements on traffic (traffic level; modal mix; and frequency, reliability and cost of transport services) is progressively being accumulated. It is these changes in traffic, resulting from the road improvements, that generate the longer-term economic and social impacts of the investments. The evidence from the SEM&E work, including that carried out under the RRMIMP, is that FRB road improvements to all-weather standard result in a growth of motorized and non-motorized vehicular traffic and some transfer of pedestrian trips to more efficient motorized and non-motorized modes, a reduction in transport charges and an increase in the total movement of goods and people. Provision of an all-weather road tends to stimulate the operation of bus services (except on short roads) and auto- rickshaw (tempo) services. Use of rickshaw services also tends to increase, but rickshaw traffic grows at a slower rate than motorized services. However the use of bullock carts on the FRBs tends to decline. R. Ahmed and M. Hossain. Developmental Impact of Rural Infrastructure, Bangladesh. International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) in collaboration with Bangladesh Institute of Development Studies (BIDS), 1990
 95 Annex 1.4 Page 2 of 5 The FRB road investments under the ongoing RRMIMP project have already had a demonstrable socio- economic impact, as a result of increased traffic volumes, a switch to more efficient modes of transport, and reduced transport costs. Based on the SEM&E survey of nine completed project roads in the first year of project completion (1995): * Total traffic volumes (passenger-km and tonne-km) on the nine roads increased by 120% for passengers and 300% for goods. This data set includes one road where there was a huge increase in goods traffic volume. However, comparing the median values passenger traffic volume increased by 100% and goods traffic volume by 140%. * Average daily motorized traffic on the nine roads increased by 154%. The major increases were in buses (from zero to 14 vehicles per day), motor cycles (178% increase) and auto rickshaws (100%). Non-motorized traffic increased by 90%, the major increase being in passenger rickshaws and rickshaw vans (197%). Bullock cart traffic decreased by 54%. * Average unit transport costs decreased by 69% for passengers and 48% for cargo. The benefits to rickshaw operation of a smooth running surface are shown by the fact that the transport charges of rickshaw van operators reduced by nearly 40%. The same study also showed that along improved roads compared to non-improved roads, net farm income is about 9% higher, cropping intensity 1-2% higher, and fertilizer and pesticide use respectively 4-5% and 34% higher. The overall economic return from the road improvement investments is about 26% based on partial benefits of transport cost savings. The report of findings from the monitoring of the first phase of RDP-14, the GTZ-financed Tangail Infrastructure Development Project, was published at the end of 19942. Its findings on the impact of improving FRB roads to bitumen-surfaced standard are as follows: * Within one year of FRB improvement, transport charges decreased significantly. Average passenger charges dropped by 18.7%, and average cargo charges by 23.3%. The most significant decreases in charges were for passenger rickshaws and rickshaw vans. * On two FRB roads where improvements had been initiated at the start of the monitoring study and were essentially complete by the end of the study, the total number of road users (based on average daily traffic) increased by 43% over a period of about one year, the number of non- motorized vehicle trips increased by 85% and the number of motor vehicle trips by 135 %. The number of pedestrian trips declined. Regular bus services had commnenced on one of the roads. These traffic growth rates can be compared with an average of 12.7% normal annual growth of non-motorized traffic over a ten-year period, and 7.0% for motor vehicles, derived from a control road where traffic counts were taken in 1984 and 1994. Macro-Economic Analysis As part of the IDA/LGED Rural Infrastructure Strategy Study7, macro-level analysis of the rural road network has been carried out. There is a close association between the spatial distribution of good rural roads across the country and the distribution of agricultural production densities, showing that Govermment's past policies under the Strategy for Rural Development Projects, and the resulting regional investments, have led to a generally rational distribution of resources. An analysis of the relationship between agricultural productivity and the condition of the rural road network has been carried out, using a nationwide District-level regression model. The key findings are as follows: * With statistical significance at the 5 % and 1 % confidence levels respectively, the densities of good Feeder roads and paved Rural Roads have positive productivity elasticities. The analysis suggests that an increase of 10% in the density of good Feeder roads is associated with an increase of almost 1 % in agricultural productivity. The same increase in the density of paved Rural Roads is associated with a 0.5 % increase in agricultural productivity. * Analysis using the density of all rural roads does not yield significant results, indicating that it is the condition, not the extent of the network that is important. * There is a negative relationship between agricultural productivity and gap density (measured as the number of gaps per km of FRB and Rural Road). 7 SAI Infrastructure Division of the World Bank in association with LGED. Procedures Used in the Selection of FRBs, Growth Centre Markets and Ghats 1. The FRB, market and ghat investment schemes have been selected (as listed in Annex 2.2) using the 6-step procedure which is summarised below: 1.1 An inventory was prepared of all FRB roads and Growth Centre markets in the project area. The inventory of Growth Centres included those designated in the early 1980s and the additional markets designated as Growth Centres in 1993. In preparing the inventory a strict definition of FRBs eligible for consideration under the project was applied, based on two criteria: (a) All FRBs should connect to a Growth Centre located remote from the RHD road network; (b) No Growth Centre should have more than one FRB road connection. 1.2 The inventory of FRB roads and Growth Centres was then screened to prepare ong lists of 'possible' investment schemes excluding all FRBs and markets included in the RRMIMP and RDP-6 projects', all other FRBs improved to good, all-weather bitumen- surfaced standard under other programs, and all Growth Centre markets under the Pourashava Parishad or at serious risk from erosion. 1.3 Using the long-list of possible schemes as the starting point, participatory meetings were organised in each of the 97 Thanas in the project area, attended by local representatives including Union Parishad members, NGOs and beneficiaries. At these meetings the local representatives were requested to discuss, reach a consensus on, and rank, their priorities for FRB and Growth Centre markets. They were also asked to identify priority ghats for improvement in the Thana. The meetings were facilitated by the preparation consultants' staff, but the consensus and decisions were reached by local representatives through open debate. During this field work consultations were also held with TNOs, LGED staff and some Members of Parliament. 1.4 The locally-defined priorities were used to prepare short-lists of 'probable' FRB upgrading and Growth Centre market improvement schemes. The short-lists were based on indicative targets for the extent and distribution of the physical investment schemes across the project area, aimed at achieving approximately equivalent coverage at project-end in relation to the infrastructure needs of the Northwest Region and the Three FRB roads which RDP-6 will upgrade only to HBB standard were included for possible bitumen- surfacing.
 100 Annex 2.1 Page 2 of 8 Greater Dhaka Area. In preparing the short-lists the greatest weight was given to the locally-defined priorities determined during the participatory meetings. However some adjustments were made to reflect rational selection criteria, as follows: (a) Most FRBs less than 2km long were excluded; (b) A few FRBs were added where particular requests had been made and where initial field investigations indicated that the roads were important; (c) Growth Centre markets located very close to existing, improved markets were excluded; (d) Some priority was given to complementing existing RRMIMP investments by short-listing unimproved Growth Centre markets located on FRBs improved under the RRMIMP; and (e) Priority was given to short-listing both FRBs and the markets that they serve, but in some cases FRBs were short-listed without the accompanying market. 1.5 a) All short-listed FRBs were subjected to detailed economic appraisal, based on initial inventory surveys to prepare estimates of improvement costs, and on traffic surveys to provide the data for estimation of economic benefits. The final list of selected FRBs was made based on the results of the economic analysis, rejecting all roads with an EIRR of less than 12% and selecting those with the highest EIRRs. b) Economic and physical data was collected from the field for all short-listed Growth Centre markets and for all ghats identified locally as priorities. The final list of selected Growth Centre markets was derived from the short-list, primarily based on the locally-identified priorities but: (i) Eliminating any markets located on FRB which do not provide, and which will not be upgraded under the project to provide, all-weather access; (ii) Choosing between alternatives where adjacent Thanas had prioritised markets located very close together - in such cases the more important market was chosen based on the economic data collected; and (iii) Eliminating certain markets where the field data raised serious doubts about viability of improvement, most commonly where the available land area is very small, or where the market has very low lease value, attendance and turnover. c) The final list of selected ghats was made, from the priorities identified by local representatives, as follows: (i) Since most of the priority ghats serve markets, all ghats serving Growth Centre markets selected for improvement under the project or

Introduction Participation of major stakeholders and beneficiaries has been incorporated into the design of the project from the start of preparation. The Feeder Roads, markets and ghats for improvement have already been selected through a process of participation to identify local priorities (see Annex 2.1). The remaining components will follow similar procedures. During the course of project preparation, major opportunities have been identified to expand the scope of participation. SAR, paragraphs 3.1 to 3.5 sunmmarize the main participatory features of the projects. It is a very fortunate situation for the project preparation that all parties are very positive about the participatory approach. The Local Government Engineering Department (LGED) has become an enthusiastic promoter of the participatory approach; this is very important because co-ordination by LGED at the national level ensures that successful approaches will be replicated in the whole country. Also the National Planning Commission has made participation a major emphasis of their new development plan under preparation. This is clearly implied by the title of the document under preparation: "Participatory Perspective Plan for Bangladesh 1995 2010". As part of the preparation work a series of studies have been carried out on different aspects of participation, the findings of which are presented in four working papers produced in early 19951. This note, which supplements discussions in SAR (paragraphs 3.1 to 3.5), summarises the findings from the work on participation, and the participatory measures that will be applied in the implementation of the different components of the project. 2. Context * In the context of LGED rural infrastructure development activities, there is an array of stakeholders in participation: LGED, and its staff at HQ, District and Thana level. The rural communities such as rural social leaders, landless men and women, men and women professionals, destitute men and women, etc. Particular target and interest groups among the rural communities - e.g. poor women and men, men and women market users, boat operators, lessees, etc. 'Community Participation in Rural Infrastructure Development' by Dr. Dee Jupp. 'Use of Labour Contracting Societies in Rural Infrastructures' by Mr. Mohammed Faizullah. 'Financing Local Level Infrastructures' by Mr. Mohammed Faizullah. 'Institutional Issues in Participation' by Dr. M. Rashiduzzaman. (These are included in Project Files; see Annex 4.1)
 115 Annex 2.3 Page 2 of 11 - NGOs, youth clubs, women's organisations etc., who may have a role to play in particular aspects of participation. - Local government bodies - Union Parishads (UP) including their women members, Thana Development Co-ordination Committees (TDCC), Market Management Committees (MMC) including women representatives, and Ghat Management Committees (GMC). - Officials of Central Government working at local level - Deputy Commissioner (DC), Thana Nirbahi Officer (TNO), District Women Affairs Officer etc. - Local Government Division (LGD) responsible for local government, and National Institute of Local Government (NILG). - Project Beneficiaries: including users of rural roads, structures, markets, river jetties, i.e. most of the rural population in the project areas. * There are four levels of Participation: 1. Information Sharing 2. Consultation 3. Shared Control over Decision-Making 4. Initiation of Action Participation should be perceived as encompassing all aspects of rural infrastructure development. However it must be practical and manageable, and will involve different stakeholders, and operate at different levels, for different aspects: - Planning and Selection of Infrastructure Schemes - Detailed Design of Infrastructure Schemes - Implementation of Infrastructure Works - Monitoring of Infrastructure Works - Operation and Maintenance of Infrastructure - Financing of Infrastructure Improvement and Maintenance. * Many aspects of LGED's activities already involve participation, and it has embarked upon a number of initiatives to develop more participatory approaches: - it is a rural infrastructure development agency with a genuine poverty focus in its work, has a significant presence throughout the country at local-level (Thana and District) and inter-acts with different stakeholders at local-level. the concept of LGED staff as 'social engineers' is emerging, training in socio- economic issues is being developed, and LGED is taking steps to strengthen its 'social' staffing capacity - most importantly by the conversion of selected staff in each Thana office to the post of 'community organiser', and the provision of training to these community organisers. LGED is already involved in developing planning capacity at union and thana level, e.g. through extensive training, the use of the Union and Thana Plan Books, and is refining procedures to increase the level of participation. LGED's existing training programs needs to be reviewed and tailored according to the needs of the project.
 116 Annex 2.3 Page 3 of II LGED already works with UPs and TDCCs in the implementation of different programs, e.g. the Growth Centre Connecting Roads (GCCR) program, and the Integrated Food for Development (IFFD) project which LGED implements with CARE. LGED pioneered the concept of Labour Contracting Societies in Bangladesh to exploit the opportunities of infrastructure works to provide employment for the rural poor men and women (see attachment 1) LGED is now expanding this concept to employ disadvantaged, assetless women for routine maintenance, tree caretaking on FRBs, and other infrastructure building activities. As part of the development of the FRB maintenance system, LGED is involving the UPs in monitoring of maintenance works. LGED is now addressing the needs of women at improved markets. * LGED's participatory approach has been further developed in the preparation of the RRMIMP- 2 project - a participatory approach has been adopted for the pre-selection of FRBs, Growth Centre markets and ghats for improvement under the project, involving group discussions at Thana level with representatives including women members of each Union (together with the Thana Engineer and the TNO) to identify and rank local priorities for improvement. * Activities under the project should aim to build upon, reinforce and extend existing LGED initiatives in participation. However there are some institutional issues that extend beyond LGED and relate to the Local Government Division of the Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development and Co-operatives (MLGRD&C). 3. Community Participation in Infrastructure Development * The project area covers 14 Districts, 97 Thanas, 960 Unions and about 22 million people. Initiatives under the project in respect of community participation must be both practical and manageable within the scale of the project. * Field investigations have been carried out to assess the scope and identify the mechanisms for community participation in selection of schemes (SRR), in detailed design (markets and ghats), and in monitoring (SRR, markets and ghats). Specific attention was given to the participation of women in these aspects. * The key findings from the field investigations are as follows: Rural people including target and interest groups (the end-users) would like to become more involved in the selection and design of rural infrastructure schemes - SRR, Markets, Ghats. They have something valuable to offer in terms of their local knowledge of needs and priorities, and in recommending detailed design improvements.
 117 Annex 2.3 Page 4 of 11 Simple mapping exercises by road users (men & women) provide a good basis for community discussion on priorities for SRRs, and for presenting proposals to officials. Group discussions and ranking exercises provide a mechanism for users' requirements and priorities to be incorporated into the design of market and ghat improvements. End-users are ill-informed about proposed development initiatives, about decision- mraking processes and about procedures for operation and management of rural infrastructure (e.g. markets). End-users are also ill-informed about sources and allocation of funds. More information will result in greater transparency and will allow 'monitoring from below'. Women are increasingly using roads and markets, and should be involved in community participation processes. Market improvement schemes offer an opportunity to stimulate increased use by women. Women groups, and NGOs that promote income-generating activities for women, should be involved in determiining the need for, and the design of, any special market facilities for women and in monitoring of its implementation. Market and ghat users indicate that they would be prepared to pay increased tolls for improved facilities as long as they are consulted about the improvements. Community discussions indicate that people have some reservations about the role of NGOs in participatory planning, particularly in acting on their behalf as 'advocates' to higher authorities. NGOs may also be reluctant to take on this role. However there are possibilities for NGOs to support LGED in developing participatory planning capability. A participatory process demands people to develop their capacity to question about the issues that relate to them. So, NGOs who have the objectives of social mobilisation to ascertain people's rights need to be selected. * The findings from the field investigations indicate that initiatives under the project in respect of community participation should focus on: i) providing more information to rural men and women on infrastructure development and management in their locality; ii) involvement of communities (men and women) in selection of SRR; iii) involvement of men and women users in the design of market and ghat improvements; iv) involvement of men and women groups in result based monitoring. To enable them to do the monitoring using selected indicators will require field testing and training since they will need to understand and to be familiarised with the indicators in order to play an effective role. * Based on these conclusions, the project will incorporate two approaches to community participation: 1 . Throughout the project area 'Information Sharing' and feed back mechanisms will be incorporated into the project. The aim is to inform rural people about: broad plans in place for the area under the project, how these have been made, and the financial implications including contributions that will be made by local bodies. aspects of the project where people can make an input to selection and design (SRR, markets, ghats), and the channels for making their inputs.
 118 Annex 2.3 Page 5 of 11 - decisions that are made about, reasons for such decisions, and arrangements for implementation of, investment schemes in their locality. - procedures for the operation and maintenance of infrastructure, sources and allocation of funds, and responsibilities of local bodies (particularly in respect of Rural Roads, markets and ghats). The UPs will be an important partner in the process of information sharing. They will require training and support from the LGED Community Organisers (who will also require training in information dissemination techniques) and/or from other non government organisations. A range of appropriate methods will be used for dissemination of different types of information including: - 'banging' of drums - a traditional method for spreading news. This should also be done in the residential areas so that women get the information. - distribution of flyers. - public meetings. - posting of notices in prominent places, e.g. presentation of plans for market improvement, and listing of members of the market management committee, in Growth Centre markets. - advertising (of the SRR schemes). - use of local institution such as schools, madrasha, NGOs and social leaders. This information sharing approach will include feed back from the beneficiaries and sharing of information on problems faced, lessons learnt, strengths and weaknesses of the implemented activities, special provisions for women in different activities, and facilitate 'monitoring from below'. The project will monitor the performance and effectiveness of the information sharing approach and methodologies. 2. In a more targeted manner, community participation will be taken a stage further by adopting a 'Users Input' approach: i) for the detailed design of Markets and Ghats, the approach will be applied extensively to the proposed improvement schemes, but with representative samples of users. Group discussions and ranking exercises will be used to define local priorities for specific improvements and to provide inputs on detailed aspects of design. This Users Input approach will be integrated into the standard LGED procedure for physical planning and design of market improvements. Draft plans and designs for improvement will be posted in each market/ghat for review prior to finalisation. ii) for the SRR component, an extensive application of this approach will be made in selected 'pilot' Districts, and in sample communities in those Districts, identification of priorities for SRRs through mapping exercises will be facilitated; the communities (men and women) encouraged and assisted to represent their priorities to local officials; and participation in monitoring will be included. Because of the national activities of this component (i.e. also outside the project area of all the other components) the extensive approach cannot be applied everywhere, yet for all the projects some level of participation of beneficiaries, at least consultation by UP will be done.

Participatory Processes in the Different Components of the Project Participation is build in into the different components of the project. The main features of each component are summarised below. 4.1. Feeder Roads Type B (FRB) Component The FRB roads to be improved under this component have been selected using a participatory approach involving consultation with local bodies - Union Parishads, TDCCs and NGOs - to derive a short-list of roads based on local priorities, which were then subjected to economic appraisal. 4.2. Maintenance component: Road User Committees There is a need for involving road users in setting priorities for the development and maintenance of the network. As roads are improved bus and truck operations become more important and the opinions of bus and truck operators do matter, this is also true for the business community in general. Since the road network provides also access to social services, the opinions of officials and users of health and educational infrastructure are also important. Therefore the project emphasizes the creation of Road User Committees. These committees will approve maintenance schemes and may be involved with the approval of future investment schemes, these committees will include all above mentioned stakeholders.  125 Annex 2.4 Page 1 of 5 BANGLADESH SECOND RURAL ROADS AND MARKETS IMPROVEMIENT AND MAINTANCE PROJECT PILOT PROGRAM TO IMPROVE NON-MOTORISED TRANSPORT (NMT) 1. Background Non-motorised transport (NMT) plays a very important role in the rural transport system in Bangladesh, and foremost among the different types of NMT are the cycle rickshaws. There are estimated to be at least 300,000 cycle rickshaws in rural areas, comprising passenger rickshaws (which mainly carry people but also move goods) and rickshaw vans (which mainly move goods but also carry people). Cycle rickshaws provide affordable, flexible, demand-responsive and extensive transport services in rural areas. They complement motor vehicle services on improved roads and provide the main means of transport for rural people and their goods on lower levels of the network where, because of poor road conditions, motor vehicles operate only with difficulty or not at all. Cycle rickshaws give rural people in Bangladesh who cannot afford to own any means of transport of their own a level of mobility which is not possible in other rural societies that do not have such vehicles. A recent study on the impact of non-motorized transport on rural household's activity patterns showed that of 100 sample households none had any motorized vehicle, only 12 percent had a bicycle and 4 percent owned boats. The study further revealed that less than 1 percent of the activities to which the household had to have access could be accessed solely using motorized vehicles; the rest had to be done using either NMT (13 percent) or walking (41 percent) or any combinations of, predominantly non-motorized modes (31 percent). Accordingly, there exists an enormous potential demand for NMT to assist in meeting household's basic socio-economic transport needs. The potential for motor vehicles to meet rural household's day to day transport demand is negligible because they are not affordable: 31 percent of the households ruled out use of any type of vehicle, even in the case of emergency, simply because they are beyond their financial means. Of the 69 percent who can afford vehicle use, only 20 percent can afford motorized vehicles, while the remaining 80 percent can afford only NMT. It was found that the time saved by the introduction of NMT would be used mainly for productive purposes (44 percent and 23 percent for resp. work and domestic tasks). NMT are well- suited to many of the mobility demands of rural people - travel over relatively short distances and movement of relatively small volumes of goods. The RRMIMP-2 project traffic counts carried out on 98 unimproved FRB roads in the project area give an indication of the level of use of cycle rickshaws - there is an average of 360 cycle rickshaw vehicle trips per day on each of these roads. It is estimated that at least 400,000 people in rural areas are employed in the production, operation and repair of cycle rickshaws. Most of the rural cycle rickshaws are owned by the men who pull them, and rickshaw operation is a very important source of employment for the rural poor. A recent survey by the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics found that rickshaw's share is 30 percent of the transport sector's total contribution to the GDP. There has tended in the past to be an assumption that it was not necessary to pay attention to NMT, except as a hindrance to motor traffic, as they would rapidly disappear with the improvement of the condition of the road network and economic development. There is some evidence of decline in the ownership of bullock carts and in their use on improved rural roads. However the numbers of cycle rickshaws and bicycles in rural areas is continuing to increase, especially on improved roads: recent
 126 Annex 2.4 Page 2 of 5 studies show an increase of non-motorized vehicles on the improved road network of about 40 percent one year after improvement to about 60 percent three years after improvement. NMT will continue to play an important role in the rural transport system, and remain an important means of income- generation for the rural poor, for the foreseeable future. Although these figures indicate the large potential of NMT in meeting the transport needs of the rural poor, there is the potential danger that the positive impact will be biased towards males and the wealthier classes. Women's activity patterns show a low involvement in direct income generating activities (on average 6.3 hrs per day is spent on domestic tasks, only 1.1 hr on income generating activity). Cultural factors play a central role here and the proposed NMT project will include careful investigation of the social, cultural, and economic factors related to the use of NMT. The bicycle is the first means of independent, wheeled transport that a rural Bangladeshi can afford to own. The ownership and use of bicycles can therefore be expected to continue to increase as rural incomes increase. In rural areas bicycles have the advantages that they can be used to carry significant amounts of goods as well as the rider, and they can be used on earthen tracks and narrow footpaths (where larger vehicles cannot move) as well as on the road network. 2. Design, Manufacturing and Financing Issues The design of cycle rickshaws - passenger rickshaws and rickshaw vans - is based on bicycle technology. They use a standard bicycle frame with the rear wheel removed, bicycle front forks, and the bicycle front brake (rear brakes are not fitted). The extended rear frame, the rear axle, and the passenger or goods-carrying body of the cycle rickshaws are fabricated in local workshops and bolted on to the bicycle frame. There have been some innovations in design - stronger wheels on rickshaw vans and minor variations in body designs - but to a very large extent the cycle rickshaws have remained unchanged for many years, except for some regional adaptations. The result of the unchanged technology is that cycles rickshaws are widely available throughout the country and can be produced, maintained and repaired anywhere. On the other hand the present designs are technically deficient in many ways - they require great effort in pedalling, they have limited load space, and have insufficient braking capacity. They are also subject to frequent breakdown - broken wheels, punctured tyres, damaged frames and front forks - and require a lot of maintenance and repair. Bullock carts are a traditional technology in Bangladesh, and are produced by highly skilled carpenters in roadside workshops. The traditional, large wooden cart wheels, sometimes with iron plated rims, are inefficient, and are a source of damaged to improved roads - in 1993 the Local Government Division issued a circular that requires bullock carts used on paved roads to be fitted with rubber-tyred wheels. There could be potential to increase the load carrying-capacity and utility of bicycles in Bangladesh through the introduction of bicycle trailers, particularly since the same basic design could also be used as a hand-cart - a similar initiative is having growing success in Sri Lanka. Small scale introduction and testing of such transport innovations that are successful in other countries is included in the pilot program, with special attention for the transport needs of women, including addressing current design constraints.
 127 Annex 2.4 Page 3 of 5 There have been several previous initiatives to improve the design of NMT in Bangladesh, and in particular to improve the design of cycle rickshaws. These initiatives have had no significant impact on the many cycle rickshaws in use in rural areas, for several reasons: * The emphasis was purely on technical improvement to make the cycle rickshaws more efficient, based on 'outsiders' perceptions of what was required, rather than basing innovations on the needs and priorities of the rickshaw pullers, makers and users and setting the technical developments in the context of the social and economic conditions within which cycle rickshaws function. * The emphasis was on producing completely new designs of cycle rickshaws which were different from the traditional technology, and which proved to be more expensive. The successful adoption of these improved designs therefore required the rickshaw owners to invest in a completely new, costly and, in their eyes unproven, technology. This they were reluctant to do. Also, the new designs tended not to be suited to manufacture in the existing workshops. * To overcome the problems of cost, there was a tendency to try and introduce the new designs through co-operatives. However co-operatives are rare among rural rickshaw pullers who operate as individual owner-riders, although they do often form into local associations to protect their common interests. No attempts were made to co-ordinate technical innovation with the provision of credit for purchase of the new cycle rickshaws. Market prices of new passenger rickshaws vary from Tk 8,000 to Tk 9,000, while prices of rickshaw vans are slightly lower at Tk 6,000-7,000. Prices of used vehicles vary from Tk 3,000 to Tk 3,800. Monthly net income of rickshaw pullers varies from Tk 1,500 to Tk 1,700, with similar income levels for rickshaw van pullers. Both categories reported that the monthly income reported is the only source of income. Depending on the family size, their monthly expenditures vary from Tk 1,000 to Tk 1,500, making it very hard to put aside savings. Commercial banks do not finance the purchase of NMT, regarding it as too risky. A number of NGOs who operate as rural credit financing agencies offer loans to the rural poor which can, inter-alia, be used to buy cycle rickshaws. However, in most cases the loans are not tailored specifically to rickshaw purchase - thus, for example, the maximum credit limit may be too low for a poor person to buy a new cycle rickshaw.

Objective, Benefits and Strategy for the Pilot Program to Improve NMT The objective of the pilot program is to improve the performance and safety, increase the reliability, improve the efficiency and load-carrying capacity, and increase the passenger comfort of NMT. The benefits will be reduced operating costs and improved levels of transport services at lower fares, thus increasing the contribution of NMT to an efficient rural transport and trading system, and sustaining and increasing the opportunities for the rural poor to generate income from production, operation and repair of NMT. Furthermore, in combination with upgrading rural roads to all year accessibility (not necessarily for motorized vehicles, but at least for NMT) under the project, mobility and accessibility of the rural poor to centers of economic activity, health and education will be improved substantially. The strategy for the pilot program to improve NMT is determined primarily by learning from past failures, and adopting an approach that will maximise the chances of success. The key features of the strategy are as follows: The program will focus first on improvements in cycle rickshaw design, second on design improvements for bullock carts (with emphasis on alternatives for narrow-rimmed, damaging wheels). Thirdly, the program will also examine the problems faced by women in using NMT for their transport tasks and will introduce adapted designs (e.g. women bicycles) to cater for women's transport needs. On a small scale, the program will demonstrate successful technologies, developed abroad, such as bicycle trailers and wheelbarrows. The program will learn by experience, and have the flexibility to adjust priorities based on that experience. * The program will not attempt to introduce a 'better rickshaw'. Rather it will focus on improvements to the design of specific aspects of the cycle rickshaw - eg. bodywork, transmission, braking, front fork, wheels, etc. - which can be retro-fitted to existing rickshaws as well as incorporated into newly-manufactured vehicles, and which can be produced in the existing workshops. This will allow the many thousands of existing rickshaw pullers to benefit from the improvements without making a large investment in a new vehicle. * The program will work from the start together with its target groups - rickshaw owners and pullers, rickshaw makers, bullock cart owners and makers, and women. It will be guided by their priorities for design improvements, and will work in partnership with them to develop, test, modify and finalize the improved designs. * The program will emphasize the promotion and dissemination of the improved designs within the project area and to other parts of the country, and the provision of credit to the rural poor to purchase the improved designs. To this end it will from the start generate the interest of, and involve, rural credit financing agencies and government, NGO and private sector actors who can contribute to dissemination. * One successful technology to be demonstrated is a simple wheel-making technology, developed and proven by the Intermediate Technology Development Group (ITDG), which can be used
 129 Annex 2.4 Page 5 of 5 by existing small workshops to make strong, light, low-cost wheels for rickshaws, for rubber- tyred bullock carts, for bicycle trailers and for other NMT. 4. Implementation of Pilot Program The pilot program will be in two Phases - Development and Dissemination - each of two years duration. LGED will sub-contract the implementation of the program to an NGO, with the first phase beginning in January 1997. The contracted NGO will combine the capability to work in a participatory manner with grassroot NGOs and target groups in rural areas with the technical capacity needed to develop the improved designs and the resources to organise and conduct training of local workshops in the project area. Limited provision is made in Phase 1 for technical assistance to support the NGO in technical and socio-economic aspects. LGED will select the NGO to execute the program, following the Bank's Guidelines for the Use of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers and by the World Bank as Executing Agency. To avoid delays in implementation of the component, LGED will invite shortlisted NGOs no later than September 1, 1996, to submit their proposals and award the contract for Phase I by March 10, 1996.

Objectives, Policy and Administrative Issues Training is the essential method for acquiring knowledge, skills and for changing attitude in order to cope with the quickly changing world. Development of competence of staff within LGED is prerequisite in order to: assume the wider role played by LGED in rural infrastructure development - not only related to hard-core engineering but also related to other aspects of development, like, monitoring impact of infrastructure on socio-economic development, community participation in infrastructure planning etc.; take up the challenging tasks of increased work-load; and cope with the rapidly changing technology with regard to infrastructure planning, development and maintenance. With donors' support LGED has taken a very ambitious program for the staff and some groups outside LGED . On top of the program undertaken by LGED with regard to training of LGED staff, there is still some opportunity to support LGED in its effort to develop trained manpower in order to cope with the added responsibility warranted by this project and other projects. The following sections deal with the current aspects of training in LGED; objectives, policy and administrative aspects of the training program to be undertaken under this project. 2. Training and LGED The training activities at LGED started in the former Works Program Wing (WPW) in 1981 which gained a real momentum in 1984 with the establishment of Local Government Engineering Bureau (LGEB). At present all training programs in LGED are coordinated and implemented through the Head Quarter Training Unit (HQTU) at Dhaka and fifteen other District Training Centers (DTC). The Training Unit is headed by a Superintending Engineer (SE) who is assisted by an expatriate Training Adviser and local training specialists and two Senior Training Specialists (STSs), three Training Specialists (TSs), one Assistant Training Specialist (ATS) and fifteen District Training Officers (DTOs). District Executive Engineers of LGED provide administrative support to the DTOs when required. The responsibilities of the LGED Training Units include: * develop an overall policy for LGED training * assess training needs for different categories of staff * develop training materials for all courses * arrange and conduct training courses at HQ and district levels in order to fulfill national training requirements in the sector * arrange and conduct on-the-job-training during preparation and implementation of schemes * provide assistance for specific training programs of all projects under LGED X Action plan for Direction in Management Development of LGED, Report of the Management Capability Strengthening (MANCAPS) project, ISO, Swedish Management Group, 1995
 138 Annex 2.6 Page 2 of 5 * arrange conferences, seminars, workshops, study tours etc. for LGED Training Unit provides training for Projects Directors (PDs), Executive Engineers (XENs), Thana Engineers/Assistant Engineers and other staff at the Thana and District level. The training program is based on the a need assessment made five years ago. Currently another need assessment exercise is being conducted by the Training Unit. Future training program will be based on the needs assessed from this exercise. HQTU is responsible for the overall coordination of all training courses. The courses offered by the HQTU are conducted by the concerned TS. DTOs conduct those courses which are conducted in the district level. The HQTU and District offices of the Training Unit are organized and well equipped with modern teaching aids and the staff are professionally competent. * In addition to the implementation of the National Training Program, HQTU of LGED also centrally coordinate the training courses planned under different projects implemented by LGED. The TU also provides assistance to different projects in conducting project specific training courses. The TU has also shown its flexibility in responding to the needs of LGED arise from time to time due to the change of training needs - like training on environmental and socio-economic aspects - and targeted trainee - like, contractors, laborers. 3. Objectives of the Training Program Under the Project 3.1 Immediate Objectives: * to increase capability of LGED staff to implement project components effectively; * to increase capability of local government bodies (Union Parishads, Market and Ghat Management Committees) with respect to local level infrastructure planning following users input approaches; * to increase technical and management capability of local contractors. 3.2 Long-Term Objectives * to increase sustainability and efficiency of rural infrastructure investments with optimum input from all actors in the process. 4. Training Strategies The training component of the project will have the following strategies: * the component will play a complementary role to the ongoing training activities of LGED; * the courses offered under the training component will be chosen in such a way that it will have sustainable impact; * the project will finance on priority basis training related to the components either first introduced with an option for institutionalization or other components with an options for institutionalization in this rural development project - participatory planning, equipment management and cost

Training Under RRMIMP 2 5.1 Local Training The project specific training activities under the project will include, inter alia, the following: (i) Training on Management/Project Management (ii) Planning (including condition surveys), contracting, supervision and inspection, and monitoring and reporting of road maintenance. (iii) Courses on construction method, quality control, and reporting procedures for construction of FRBs and FRB structures, markets and ghats. (iv) Courses on construction method, quality control and reporting procedures for construction of drainage structures on rural roads, which is a major component of the project. TOR FOR SMALL-SCALE CONTRACTING INDUSTRY STUDY Objectives of the Study The objectives of the study are: 1 . To develop a better understanding of the nature and characteristics of small-scale civil engineering contractors who work, or wish to work, for LGED and of the technical, financial, commercial and management constraints to their development. 2. To advise on improvement of the existing measures that are being applied, and additional measures that could be adopted, by LGED under the RRMIMP-2 to increase the capability of contractors in the project area, particularly in respect of their technical and management skills, their ability to bid for and implement higher value and more technically demanding contracts, and their level of ownership of equipment. 3. To identify broader measures that could be adopted by LGED, and by LGED in co-ordination with other agencies such as the Roads and Highways Department (RHD) and in the context of future donor-supported projects, to develop the small-scale civil engineering contracting industry in Bangladesh and to promote the development of a thriving plant hire contracting industry. Scope of Works 1 . Review of LGED and RRMIMP-2 pre-qualification, tendering and contracting documents and procedures, and of their experience with small-scale contractors (through discussions with LGED staff at HQ, project, District and Thana level) and of earlier initiatives to develop contractor capability. 2. Review of the activities in respect of contractor development, and of equipment management by LGED, that are being carried out under RRMIMP-2. 3. Review of initiatives to develop standard contract documents for donor-financed small infrastructure works in Bangladesh, and to establish common pre-qualification of contractors by LGED and RHD. 4. Preparation of an overview of the extent and characteristics of the small-scale contracting industry, primarily through examination of LGED's records and procedures for pre-qualifying contractors to work on RDP projects, and of their experience of these contractors. This, together with analysis of other sources of information will provide the basis to develop an assessment of the extent of the small-scale contracting industry, and a classification of different
 143 Annex 2.7 Page 2 of 11 categories of small-scale contractors based on key indicators such as equipment owned, number of skilled and qualified staff, and types of work that they are able to undertake. 5. Based on this analysis, a detailed survey (which might include workshops with groups of contractors) of a cross-section of different categories of small-scale contractors in the project area. This cross-section will include contractors pre-qualified for and working on RRMIMP-2 contracts (some of these in the RDP-7 areas will have several years of experience of such work, while others in the Greater Dhaka area will have only limited experience); and other contractors who wish to work for LGED, including those who have failed to pre-qualify and those who undertake smaller works for the RHD. The purposes of the survey are to: i) define the business structure and financial situation of the different categories of small- scale contractors, and identify the financial constraints that they face in taking on different types of contract with LGED and other agencies; ii) define the numbers and types of unskilled, skilled, and qualified staff that they employ, and the basis of employment (e.g. casual, fixed-term or permanent); iii) assess the perceptions of small-scale contractors about the long-term security of their businesses, the types and level of commercial risks involved, and the constraints that they face in investing in longer-term business development (e.g. in employing technical staff on a permanent basis); iv) examine the attitudes towards and constraints to investment in equipment, and attitudes towards the development of plant hire companies; v) assess needs for developing the technical and management capability of the contractors. 6. Discussions with other interested parties in Bangladesh - including other government agencies (and in particular the RHD and the Institutional Development Component of its RRMP2 project), IDA and SDC and other donor agencies, the Dhaka office of the IFC, leasing companies, equipment manufacturers and importers, banks who have small-scale contractors as clients, and contractors' associations - to assess: i) issues relating to financing of small-scale contractors by commercial banks; ii) the feasibility of and mechanisms for co-ordinated actions to develop the small contracting industry; iii) the feasibility of and mechanisms for, financing the purchase of construction equipment, including supporting the development of plant hire companies, and the possible role of the IFC; iv) the potential role of contractors' associations in assisting the development of the small- scale contracting industry. 7. Preparation of a report of findings and conclusions, together with specific recommendations on: i) improvements to existing measures, and additional measures to be adopted, by LGED under the RRMIMP-2 to increase the capability of contractors in the project area, particularly in respect of their technical and management skills, their ability to bid for and implement higher value and more technically demanding contracts, and their level of ownership of equipment;
 144 Annex 2.7 Page 3 of 11 ii) broader measures by LGED, and by LGED in co-ordination with other agencies and in the context of future donor-supported projects, to develop the small-scale civil engineering contracting industry in Bangladesh, and to encourage the development of a plant hire contracting industry, with recommendations on institutional mechanisms and implementation modalities to apply these measures. A summary of findings will be prepared, and a one-day workshop will be conducted with LGED, project, and financing agency staff, representatives of small-scale contractors and other interested parties (as defined in Para. 6 of the scope of works) to review the findings prior to the finalisation of the report. Inputs It is envisaged that the study will require: * A two-month input by an international specialist with extensive experience, including Asia region experience, of the development of small-scale civil engineering contracting industries. * Inputs of two months each by two national consultants - a contracting specialist and an enterprise development specialist, each with extensive relevant experience. * All necessary support services including transport, office services and communications. LGED and the RRMIMP-2 project will ensure all necessary advisory support and access to relevant information and personnel. 2. TOR FOR FRB REGIONAL PRIORITISATION STUDY Objectives of the Study The objectives of the study are to: * Develop guidelines for prioritising the needs for investment in improvement of FRBs between the 64 Districts in the country, which can be applied in making decisions on the geographic
 146 Annex 2.7 Page 5 of 11 allocation of financing agency resources for RDPs and GOB resources for FRB improvement. * Develop guidelines for selecting and prioritising specific FRB roads to be improved in a particular area. The findings of the study will be applied, inter-alia, as inputs to the identification and preparation of a new RDP as a follow-up to the RRMIMP-2 project. Approach, and Scope of Work The purpose of the study is not to produce a prescriptive master plan for the development of the FRB network in Bangladesh. Rather, it aims to: i) provide rational guidelines for selecting and prioritising the geographic areas for new RDP projects, for defining the scope of FRB works in those areas, and for geographic targeting of GOB FRB investments. This will be based on assessment of the present level of improved FRB provision in relation to the road network needs and to the economic status and potential, and the social situation, in the different Districts of the country; ii) develop standard guidelines, which can be applied across different FRB investment programs, for selecting and prioritising specific FRB roads for improvement, taking account of the needs for economic viability and for local participation in the selection of investment schemes to meet local priorities. The guidelines must also take account of the future availability of GOB revenue financing for routine and periodic maintenance of the improved FRBs, in order to sustain the investments made. The study will involve: 1. Review with LGED of its existing FRB data-base (comprising a comprehensive road inventory and maps), complemented by selective field surveys and collection of additional data from LGED District Offices as necessary, to define the present extent, surfacing and condition of the FRB network (including structures on FRBs) by District. 2. Review of the criteria actually used by LGED to define this network; the costs of routine and periodic maintenance of improved FRBs; and the present and likely future availability of GOB revenue funds for such maintenance. Based on this, and to the extent necessary, refine the criteria and define a smaller, 'core' maintainable FRB network and its distribution across the Districts, and assess the cost of improving and upgrading this network to good, all-weather bitumen surfaced standard. 3. Definition of easily quantifiable indicators to compare the present level of provision of improved, bitumen surfaced, good condition FRBs in the 64 Districts in relation to the present economic status, future economic potential and social situation of those Districts. This will draw upon, but refine and expand, the indicators used in the IDA/LGED rural infrastructure strategy study. 4. Using these indicators, and with selective additional field surveys as necessary, preparation of an analysis of the present level of improved FRB provision by District. 5. Based on the analysis of the maintainable FRB network and the present level of improved FRB provision: - preparation of guidelines for selecting and prioritising Districts for FRB investments;
 147 Annex 2.7 Page 6 of 11 preparation of guidelines for assessing the scope of FRB improvement works in any District; presentation of recommendations on any specific areas which are high priorities for FRB investment, and on the scope for investments there; - definition of procedures that can be applied by LGED to update the analysis of the network and the level of FRB provision. 6. Review with LGED of the methodologies used by different LGED rural infrastructure programs to select FRB investment schemes; of the LGED socio-economic monitoring and evaluation (SEM&E) activities and findings; of efforts to harmonise SEM&E in LGED; and of methodologies used in LGED for local participation in selection of priorities for FRB improvement. 7. Based on this review, and complemented by selective field investigations, preparation of guidelines for selecting and prioritising specific FRB roads to be improved in a particular area, including local participation in the identifications. 8. Review of all findings and recommendations with LGED and the IDA and the SDC prior to finalising the report.
