TOR FOR LONG-TERM SOCIO-ECONOMIC IMPACT STUDY Objective of the RRMIMP-2 Impact Study The objective of the RRMIMP-2 impact study is to evaluate the impact of FRB, Rural Road, market and ghat investments, and the resulting increased efficiency in the transport and trading system, on economic and social development within the influence area of the investments. The study will: i) analyse and quantify the effects of the FRB, Rural Road and ghat investments on transport; ii) analyse and quantify the effects of the market investments on marketing; iii) in respect of economic development, evaluate and quantify the impact of the different categories of transport investments, and of market investments, on agricultural production and productivity, business activity, direct and indirect employment, income-generation and poverty alleviation, and consumption and investment.
 148 Annex 2.7 Page 7 of 11 iv) in respect of social development, focus on evaluating and quantifying the impact of the road improvements on the efficiency and use of rural health (including family planning) and education services. The study will evaluate the impact of the investments on all sectors of the rural population in the area, but will be designed in such a way that the impact on sub-sectors of the rural population which are of special interest - the poor, destitute women, women engaged in income-generating activities, transport operators including rickshaw pullers, vehicle owners and market traders - can be evaluated. Methodology The methodology will be based on, but refined and extended from, that used for the RDP-7 impact study. In addition to the RDP-7 FRB roads for which some data has already collected, the study will focus on RRMIMP-2 FRB roads and markets to be improved (including markets where the adjacent ghat will also be improved), and Rural Roads where SRRs are to be constructed, in the 1996/97 Financial Year. Samples of these FRB and RR roads and markets (including ghats) will be selected for detailed investigation, together with 'control' roads, markets and ghats which will not be improved during the duration of the study. Benchmark Surveys will be carried out prior to the construction works, and Follow-Up Surveys will be carried out at two stages after the works have been completed - one year after completion to collect data for analysis of short-term effects and impacts; and three years after completion to collect data for analysis of longer-term effects and impacts. Based on the RDP-7 study the survey methodology will comprise: i) selection of survey villages within the influence area of, but at different distances from, each sample road and market; ii) surveys in each village with a sample of households to collect household level data. The sample will be stratified to cover different land-owning classes - landless and marginal (up to 0.4 ha.), medium (0.4-1.0 ha.) and large (more than 1.0 ha.) - plus the population sub-groups which are of special interest. The Benchmark and Follow-Up Surveys will use the same household samples; iii) community, 'key informant' and any other surveys to collect other necessary data, e.g. in relation to markets, schools, heath centres, business enterprises, price and wage levels, and the effects of the road improvements on transport; and in relation to 'special interest' sub-samples such as transport operators and market traders. Scope of Work and Implementation Arrangements The RRMIMP-2 impact study will be carried out under contract to LGED by the same consultants who are already carrying out the RDP-7 impact study. These consultants have specialised expertise in the conduct of rural impact studies, and this arrangement allows the data and findings from the RDP-7 study to be incorporated into the larger study. The study will be managed by the LGED Additional Chief Engineer (Design, Planning, Monitoring and Evaluation) and the consultants will co-ordinate with the SEM&E unit the RRMIMP-2 Project Implementation Office. The services of LGED field staff will be used to the extent possible for data collection but the consultants will be fully responsible for the efficient and effective conduct of the study, including supervision of all data collection.

It describes the responsibilities and organizational setup for the implementation of a sustained maintenance program, the funding requirements and the measures to strengthen human and institutional capacities. For the later it proposes possible links to the ongoing Institutional Development Component (IDC) of the 2nd RRMP (RHD Project funded by ODA & IDA). Regarding the implementation of maintenance it relies on the "Guidelines for Implementation of Rural Infrastructure Maintenance Program", LGED, July 1995. 1.2 The Challenge for Maintenance of Road Assets The flat and low lying terrain as well as heavy rains and high flood levels in the country require high embankments and numerous bridges and culverts to assure an all-weather transport network linking growth center markets to the national roads and to ensure the access for the rural population to those poles of development. Sufficient routine and periodic maintenance will safeguard these expensive national assets over an extended number of years. Maintenance works generate short and long term incomes to small contractors, landless farmers and destitute women. The upkeep of infrastructure will have a positive impact on agricultural production and income through reduction of transport costs. Generally speaking, sustained improvement of the life of rural (and urban) population and thus poverty alleviation will not be possible without an adequate access to economic, social and welfare services. 2. Objectives of Routine and Periodic Maintenance Components of RRMIMP-II The overall development objective of the proposed project is to increase rural incomes and reduce rural poverty by establishing an improved, sustainable rural transport and trading infrastructure. The routine and periodic maintenance of the infrastructures shall guarantee that they function over an extended period of time and safeguard the investments made. In line with the objectives of the project (see Annex 2.1) the strategy shall focus on i) planning, progranmming and implementation of routine and periodic maintenance for FRBs and structures, and important RRs in maintainable condition, ii) supporting the maintenance of SRRs, Markets and Ghats by local bodies at Thana and Union Parishad (UP) level, iii) use of the private sector for the execution of works (contractors, LCSs) and iv) support to human, institutional and technical capacity building at all institutional levels of the Project. 3. Present Responsibilities of LGED and External Support 4.1 The Local Government Engineering Department(LGED) The task and authority of the Local Government Engineering Department (LGED), an agency of the LGD, is extensively described in Annex 1.3. LGED's responsibilities which are directly relevant to the maintenance of rural infrastructures in the area of the RRMIMP-2 project are: * routine and periodic maintenance of FRBs, including structures. * the maintenance of important RR1 roads, and the maintenance of structures on Rural Roads. * the provision of technical supervision and advice to local government bodies to assist them in fulfilling their responsibilities for the operation of rural infrastructures. These responsibilities of LGED have to be seen equally in the national context of rural infrastructure development, in which the department's broader infrastructure activities include small-scale water resources, irrigation and flood control, rural water supply and sanitation, urban infrastructure development in secondary and rural towns, and construction of cyclone shelters and primary schools. Following the objectives of the Strategy for Rural Development Projects, LGED emphasizes the use of labour-intensive methods for construction and maintenance works wherever appropriate. 4.2 External Assistance to Maintenance of Rural Infrastructures Due to the fact that the Government is responsible for maintenance, only few donor- assisted projects (e.g. RDP-6 and RDP-7) gave attention to maintenance with the exception of maintenance by contractors in the first year after construction. The ADB financed RDP-18 is to be mentioned, where a long-term technical assistance on maintenance management, training, and management capability strengthening is provided, through Rural Infrastructure Maintenance Cell (RIMC). The RESP/ISP provides support to RIMC, focusing on road condition surveys. This is in the context of the improvement of the data base for planning in general at Thana level. Discussions during appraisal have shown that the coordination and integration of data collection and utilization should be further enhanced. The ISP Training Unit offers training in maintenance to District and Thana Engineering staff.

Maintenance Systems and Practices 6.1 Road (routine and periodic) Maintenance System, incl. structure Since its establishment in 1992, LGED's Rural Infrastructure Maintenance Cell (RIMC) has made considerable progress in establishing the framework for road maintenance by setting up a preliminary road inventory system, introducing national maintenance guidelines (July 1995) and establishing a training program. The assistance by ADB is in its early stages. Although coordination meetings among staff of projects supporting capacity building for maintenance (RDP-6, RDP-7 and ISP) have started, no detailed plan of action for the further development of an appropriate maintenance management system could be presented to the mission during appraisal. Such a plan of action shall be required prior to negotiation of the project. Thus it was agreed that the project will, in coordination with RIMC, introduce, test and refine a planned routine and periodic road maintenance system for the LGED network in the project area covering all FRB roads, important RR1 roads, and structures on FRBs and RRs. This will demonstrate how maintenance work can be planned and implemented effectively . It is expected that experience gathered within the project will be replicated nationally by LGED. Since there will be a significant stock of improved, bitumen-surfaced FRBs in the project area at the start of the project, the implementation of planned road maintenance will be
 157 Annex 2.8 Page 5 of 12 given immediate priority. The project will finance periodic maintenance (with the following sliding scale: 80% years 1-3, 40% in year 4 and 20% in year 5). Routine maintenance will be financed from the GOB revenue budget. The project will finance periodic maintenance of all FRBs & important RRs, and all structures on FRBs & RRs in the project area. 6.2 Monitoring and Review of GOBILGED Guidelines The guidelines of GOB/LGED define the following maintenance categories: * Routine Maintenance (day to day work including earthwork and pavement patching) * Periodic Maintenance (pavement re-sealing and structures) * Emergency Maintenance (mainly flood damages during monsoons) * Rehabilitation-type Maintenance (restoration of structure to its intended purpose) The Project will follow these guidelines but will closely monitor the proposed maintenance programs for the fourth category. It is a category of works which is normally not to be funded by maintenance budgets. The risk lays in investing funds for rehabilitation instead of maintenance. Furthermore, such funds often are used also for improvement and upgrading of roads and structures. During mid term review the experiences will be analyzed and eventually corrective measures be proposed. Although emergency maintenance needs can by definition not be predicted, the presently used system of block allocation to districts seems neither to be sufficient nor properly accounted for. Experiences will be collected and reported at mid term review with the aim to propose a more rational and efficient allocation of budgets if and when required. 6.3 Planning and Programming Planning and implementation of LGED maintenance is in principle under the responsibility of the Thana Engineer (TE). There is one Sub-Assistant Engineer (SAE) to second the TE specifically for maintenance, although this does not happen in practice. The Executive Engineer (XEN) has the approving and overall supervision authority of all such maintenance activities in his district. In order to match with the available budgets, desirable maintenance works per district and Thana need to be prioritized in an iterative programming exercise. The GOB/LGED guidelines indicate criteria for prioritization: i) FRB constructed under foreign- aided projects ii) FRB with high traffic volume iii) other FRB (partially paved, missing structures) iv) Structures on Important Rural Roads (after meeting demand of FRB) with priority on RCC structures While these criteria are practical at the present stage, where there is limited network, needing mainly routine maintenance, a rational network approach will have to be introduced to properly integrate periodic maintenance of pavements. While it is estimated that periodic pavement maintenance will be required every 5 years in average, the detailed and economically optimal timing and level of intervention has to be defined individually for the road section based on: * pavement and surface condition expected future deterioration, dependent on type and volume of traffic * available funds The project shall propose simple and flexible procedures to obtain the necessary data and define the yearly periodic and routine maintenance program. Sufficient time will be
 158 Annex 2.8 Page 6 of 12 allowed to discuss the proposed annual programs prior to approval. The schedule of the guidelines shall be monitored and any improvement can be proposed if deemed necessary. For example, the inspection of the roads has to be carried out in May, which coincides with the end of the construction season when LGED staff is generally very busy with supervision. However, with the introduction of the AE & SAE maintenance positions, this bottleneck should be removed. In the context of increased participation the project shall assist LGED in developing and introducing procedures to expand membership of the District Maintenance Committees to include user representatives (bus and truck, auto-rickshaw and rickshaw operators) in order to promote sharing of information and user input into selection of maintenance priorities. 7. Implementation 8.1 Routine Maintenance and Periodic Maintenance The routine maintenance and periodic maintenance for the project are classified as follows: a) Routine Maintenance of the Earth shoulders and Embankment Slopes, Care taking of trees and Cleaning of waterways in structures: - trimming/filling and compaction of earth shoulders and slopes and reforming the camber - cutting/removal of vegetation from road shoulders, slopes and structures - repair of rain-cuts , pot holes, ruts and rat-holes in the embankment - re-fining of turfing - care taking of trees
 160 Annex 2.8 Page 8 of 12 removal of debris from waterways/siltation cleaning of bridge deck drains and weep-holes in abutments and wing walls b) Routine Maintenance of Road Pavement and Structures: repair of potholes sealing/patching of cracks repair of depressions repair of edges filling and compaction of hard shoulders replacement of missing bricks in structures minor concrete repair to structures c) Periodic Maintenance of Road Pavement and Structures: - resurfacing - repairs of hard shoulders - replacement/repair/painting of all sign posts and guard posts - replacement of brickwork in structures - replacement of poor concrete and replastering - reforming of the railing on the bridge deck - painting of steel work 8.1.1 Work Standards and Implementation Methods Routine maintenance of embankment earth shoulders and embankment slopes, care taking of trees and cleaning of waterways in structures will be carried out by groups of disadvantaged women, providing them with long-term employment. LGED will enter into direct contracts with the group. Routine maintenance of the pavement and structures will be carried out by the contractors. Experiences in RDP-6 and RDP-7 show that the contractors are not interested in small maintenance contracts. The project will thus seek to propose and test alternative methods. One option could be, to let a contract for routine maintenance of the carriageway covering maintainable network of a district or several Thanas. Another option is the "term contract", which will let the contract of whole network of a district for a given period (usually one year). Other options could also be explored and tested by the project. The RIMC is still an early stage to develop the contracting arrangements for routine pavement maintenance. The project will assist the RIMC in developing and refining routine maintenance contracting procedures, including with respect to the testing of different options in the field. The periodic maintenance works will be carried out by the local contractors prequalified under the project using the same contracting procedures as for FRB improvement and upgrading works. The DSM consultants will prepare the engineering designs, tender documents and engineers' estimates and will assist the PIO in the evaluation of tenders and the processing of contract awards. Contracts for periodic maintenance will be let over the period September to November each year so that works can commence the following January. The periodic maintenance works will be supervised by LGED with the assistance from the DSM consultants who will certify all payments to the contractors. Quality control procedures and contractor defects liability will be the same as for FRB construction works.

Alternatively, the amount of money required for a year for cleaning and day to day maintenance of the markets, could be taken as security from lessee. One twelfth of this amount could be released at the end of each month to the lessee, provided the MMC certifies that the requisite work has been performed satisfactorily. The project will provide assistance to the formation of Ghat Management Committee and to establish an effective operation and maintenance system of the ghats, using the same procedures as for the markets. Emphasis will be placed on the setting of toll rates which will generate sufficient funds for establishing maintenance a system.

 173 Annex 3.3 Page 1 of 2 BANGLADESH SECOND RURAL ROADS AND MARKETS IMPROVEMENT AND MAINTENANCE PROJECT ASSESSMENT OF IMPLEMENTATION CAPACITY 1. Background Since the project is larger and the implementation period shorter than the ongoing project (RRMIMP-1), there is a question whether there is adequate implementation capacity to complete the project as scheduled. Implementation capacity is related to mainly the following factors: (a) the size of the project in terms of physical output; (b) the implementation period; (c) contractor capacity to complete the works; and (d) LGED's capacity to manage the project( procurement, supervision, disbursement, and monitoring). These aspects with reference to the proposed project are discussed below: (a) . (b). and :The national SRR component and NMT pilot component are reviewed separately as contractors and agencies implementing them form a different category which does not compete with the rest of the main project components which consist of the FRB roads, markets, and ghats. These latter are the items which call on contractor capacity to the maximum. (The component on periodic maintenance is an ongoing project through contractors and what the project will do is mainly to improve the quality and only to small extent more coverage). In the first project, there were 500 kms of FRB roads, 65 growth center markets and no ghats, while the present project has 575 FRB roads, 135 markets, and 41 river ghats. Market improvements and ghat construction are comparable in the complexity, period and cost of contracts ( about US $ 60,000 to 75,000 each) all done by small local contractors; one market improvement contract can be equated to a contract of about 2km FRB road improvements ( from earth to BC paving; costing about $ 200,000) in terms contractual length and difficulties. On this rough basis of output comparison, the physical output of this group of works under the first project can be equivalent to about 630 kms of FRB improvements, as against 930 km FRB works under the new project). This indicates a capacity increase of about 50% over the first project. The above increase would be more intensive annually, considering the shorter span of implementation period proposed in the second project ( five years). The first project actually would take nine years, but effectively for comparison with new project only 7 years, because its first year was lost due to delays in appointing supervision consultants and delays in issuing contracts which will not happen in the present project as consultant's appointment is a condition of Board presentation, and the first year bids would be invited before project approval by the Board; in addition, the last year of the first project was mostly to cover the contractor's defect liability period which, in the case of the new project, will fall outside the IDA-implementation period of five years due to special arrangements being made (see para ...). Combining increased size and reduced time, the new project needs to have a capacity increase of about 107 %. This increase is feasible due to the following factors: larger project area, of about 75% ( increase from 8 districts to 14 districts); these new areas have large number of suitable small contractors who operate there, as Bangladesh has a long tradition of doing many projects through contractors; these contractors usually work in their own localities, usually limited to one or two districts. (The first project's output in this group of works was produced through about 280 smnall contracts involving about 100 different contractors,
 174 Annex 3.3 Page 2 of 2 about 2.5 km road improvements per average contract, each contract running through about 10 to 15 months: Delete this later?). The project would further assist the contractors in improving their capacity and work-quality through project supervision and training as done during the first project. There has been adequate response from contractors with average three or four pre- qualified contractors bidding for each contract. The experience of recent bidding for retroactive- financing works under the new project in the new project districts showed a similar response for the about 15 contracts recently bid and awarded, indicating adequate capacity and response in these new areas as well. Thus, about 75% capacity increase can be explained from the increased project area with its own contracting capacity. The remaining extra capacity (of about 32% ) is expected from the fact that the new project is not a pilot project and is built on lessons from the first project in trying out new specifications, standards and procedures etc. ( see para..1...); LGED has become a much more experienced body (now implementing about US$1.5 billion worth of projects portfolio) and contractors have also become more experienced; the new project has also many measures to increase contractor efficiency and capacity (larger size contracts of average 4-6 km, with 2-year contracts, provision of mobilization advances for buying own equipment, higher standards in prequalifying contractors, more training, etc.); it also will give about 100 km of the roads to a new category of medium size contractors (for 10 km , US $1.0 m value contracts) who currently work on the main roads projects, who will infuse new capacity to the feeder road sector). In addition, 45 km FRB improvements have already started under retroactive financing before project approval. The second project is much better prepared and its implementation in all aspects would be more efficient. As regards the national components , the SRR components would be done through very small Labour contractors ( contracts of about $8000 each), for which there is no shortage (see para.. on SRR). The NMT component would be implemented almost entirely through experienced local NGOs with minimal supervision from LGED. 2. LGED's Capacity to Implement the Project LGED's capacity, as noted, has expanded very much under various management improvement measures, and would be further enhanced through the project and other donor support (see para...). In addition, the project would provide incremental staff in the project areas, will have a larger PIO with a separate deputy director for the new project districts as they need special attention (see para....), and will have additional staff in LGED to look after the SRR components through participatory specialists to be recruited; it will also have a large DSM consultants support appropriate for the larger size project. A new feature would be technical audit , which will carry out regular six- monthly inspection of work verification and technical quality as an additional control and monitoring tool to ensure efficient and timely project implementation. It should be emphasized here that the capacity increase of total 107% estimated above is based on a 5-year implementation period for the new project. However, a sensitivity analysis shows that if a 6- year implementation period is taken for the new project, the capacity increase needed is only about 72%, which can be easily met from the area expansion factor alone (75%); the increased capacity from efficiency factors would, in this case, provide considerable slack in capacity. This means that one strategy for reducing any risk related to implementation capacity would be to extend the implementation period by one year to 6 years at the time of the mid-term review, if considered appropriate, based on an assessment of the performance and conditions at that time.

Monitoring And Evaluation Plan 1. The proposed project would be monitored and evaluated both in terms of quantity and quality from the perspective of input, output, outcome and impact. In order that the indicators should serve an meaningful purpose, the project objectives and components/inputs has been adequately linked with the expected processes, outputs and impacts. The 'input indicators' would measure the quantity of resources provided, 'output indicators' would measure the quantity services that have been created, 'Outcome indicators' would measure the quantity of direct results that have been achieved through the provision of project goods and services and the impact indicators would measure the degree to which wider sector/project objectives are being achieved through the direct outcome of project activities. 2. The input monitoring and evaluation would focus on weather all the required resources including counterpart funding for maintenance and GOB's financing, are in place in timely fashion to implement the program activities and services. The input information would include mainly on the progress of land acquisition, and timely contract awards for the procurement of civil works, goods and consulting services. The Input indicators would be regularly monitored and assessed through quarterly and semi-annually and annually reports with an emphasis to identify problems in the delivery of inputs so that they may be resolved before causing significant delays in progress achievements. The output monitoring and evaluation would focus on the immediate results of activities, as demonstrated, for example in kms of road build, number of structures completed, number of markets developed and number of river jetties (ghats) constructed. LGED will monitor continuously all the input and output indicators through progress reports and send the reports to IDA. The summary of the progress reports would reflect the progress in respect of the proposed indicators, and in case of significant changes, the reports would specify the reasons as well as the remedial action proposed. 3. The 'Outcome' evaluation would focus on the direct results that have achieved through the provision of project's services. This would be monitored by measuring number of vehicle usage in case of feeder roads, mobility increased by increasing number of all weather rural roads, amount received on leasing of markets and ghats, amount spent on regular maintenance of markets and ghats. The Impact evaluation would measure the degree to which the project objectives are being achieved through the direct outcome of the project activities. This would include efficient service delivery to number of thanas, accessibility to number of poor communities in the rural areas, safety, cost efficiency, improve service quality to reduce transportation cost, income generated from developed market and ghats; and employment generated. It is proposed to launch a project workshops where all the stakeholders would be invited to decide the responsibilities of each stakeholders and specifically focus on how and who would maintain the baseline date for monitoring evaluation of all above referred indicators. 4. During negotiations, assurance would be sought that: (a) quarterly and annual progress reports for all project components would be prepared by the PD and submitted to the Chief Engineer LGED, who in turn will submit them to IDA; (b) a joint mid term review would be conducted by July 1999, whichever is earlier; and (c) an Implementation Completion Report would be submitted by the Government to IDA within six months of the closing date of the project. The detailed format of the quarterly and annual progress report will be agreed at negotiations.

 187 Annex 3.8 Page 1 of 10 BANGLADESH SECOND RURAL ROADS AND MARKETS IMPROVEMENT AND MAINTENANCE PROJECT LAND ACQUISITION ACTION PLAN: SUMMARY 1. Background The infrastructure works comprise construction of large numbers of small, widely scattered rural schemes. Land acquisition is required only for improvement/upgrading of FRB roads. Strucures on other FRB roads and on Rural Roads (SRR) will be built within existing alignments on public (khas) land. The local government bodies will confirm, before implementation of any market or ghat scheme commences, that there are no disputes over the public land on which the improved facilities will be constructed. If any additional land is needed, no formal land acquisition will be involved, and the local government body will arrange for purchase of the additional land prior to implementation. FRB road improvement/upgrading works will be on existing road alignments. Land, or more precisely asset, acquisition will be required to acquire: Narrow strips of land adjacent to the existing embankments in order to widen and/or raise them to meet the defined pavement cross-section standard. * On some FRB roads, land for minor re-alignment of sections of the existing embankment. * Standing trees, crops and small buildings within the widened road alignment. 2. Impacts of Land Acquisition Impacts have been assessed from a Land Acquisition Assessment (LAA) study based on surveys of the land acquisition impact of FRB improvements under the RRMIMP and the RDP-6 projects; and a Preliminary Inventory Survey of all FRB roads short-listed for improvement which included estimation of the land area, and numbers of buildings and trees to be acquired. The LAA confirmed the inadequacy of present land acquisition practices in Bangladesh. The level of compensation is generally below the full replacement value; not all affected persons receive compensation; and there can be long delays in payment of compensation, with physical occupation of the land before payment is made. Table I presents a summary of land acquisition impact by District. The project will acquire about 254ha. of land, 73% of it cultivated agricultural land, the remainder homestead land; about 260 small, pernanent 'pucca' buildings; many more 'kutcha' buildings; and large numbers of trees'. The affected persons will be owners of the agricultural, homestead and commercially developed land; owners of trees and standing crops; owners of homestead dwellings and commercial buildings; mortgagees of land, sharecroppers and agricultural labourers; renters of homestead dwellings; and owners and employees of businesses operating from commercial buildings. The environmental impact of loss of these trees will be more than compensated by the tree plantation program on all improved FRB roads.
 188 Annex 3.8 Page 2 of 10 Large numbers of people will be affected. About 24,000 households (estimated as 42 per km of FRB road) will suffer losses. About 72% of affected households will lose agricultural land, and about 36% homestead land. Land acquisition will be 'neutral' in its effect on different sectors of the rural population, ie. affected households are a normal cross-section of landowners. The level of effect will be small. Land acquisition equates to about 0.44ha per km of road or, on average, strips of land 2.2m wide on each side of the existing embankments. Thus most households will lose narrow strips of land (plus standing trees and buildings on that land) from their plots. Two-thirds of affected households will lose less than 5% of their total land-holding, 87% less than 10%, and 98.5% less than 20%. The acquisition of land may result in a few households having to re-locate their homesteads but numbers will be small, and their location cannot be determined until land acquisition is underway on each road. Land Acquisition and Compensation Policy Land acquisition will be carried out, within the legal framework of the Bangladesh Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance of 1982 and its subsequent amendments, by application of the agreed Land Acquisition Action Plan (LAAP). The LAAP accords with World Bank Operational Directive OD 4.30 in respect of minimising land acquisition, and ensuring full and prompt compensation of all project affected persons (PAPs) for loss of assets and actual temporary loss of income so that PAPs are not adversely affected.
 189 Annex 3.8 Page 3 of 10 The land acquired will be the minimum needed to improve and upgrade the FRB alignments to the defined technical standard. The alignments of the widened embankments will be carefully designed to avoid all religious/historical sites, schools and large/important buildings; and to avoid buildings where permanent businesses operate and to acquire lower value land wherever possible. Sections of road will be re-aligned only for safety reasons (to increase radii of curves), or where re-alignment has less asset acquisition impact than upgrading the existing alignment. The compensation policy is presented in Table 2. Given that the level of impact on PAPs will be small, it focuses on monetary compensation for losses. PAPs will be compensated at full replacement value for loss of assets, estimated based on assessed local current market values of the assets. PAPs will be given advance warning of land acquisition, and a three-month eviction period following payment of compensation, so that they can take actions to deal with the disruption caused, and to minimise temporary displacement problems. PAPs will also be allowed to salvage trees, standing crops and building materials as additional compensation for any temporary displacement problems. Since the area of land acquired from individual plots will be small, and PAPs will be given advance warning of land acquisition, it is not necessary to compensate mortgagees, renters or sharecroppers of agricultural land; renters of homestead dwellings; casual agricultural labourers; or for seasonal crops. Where acquisition of homestead land results in the household which owns the land and the dwelling on that land having to re-locate its homestead (defined as the plot size being reduced below 0.01 ha.) the household will receive sufficient compensation to purchase a replacement plot and construct an equivalent dwelling. The losses, and rights to compensation, of genuine uthulis (persons who construct buildings on private land with the permission of the landowner) and squatters (persons who construct buildings on private or public land without the permission of the landowner) are recognised. As owners of buildings they will be compensated for the value of the buildings. If they are operating businesses from those buildings they will be compensated for temporary loss of income. If they have trees or perennial standing crops on public land they will be compensated for the value of these. In the unlikely event that serious problems are encountered with a large concentration of genuine uthulis/squatters within the alignment of a particular road, LGED will adopt additional contingency measures, including the possibility of re-location assistance (provision of a plot of land or of a cash grant equivalent) to deal with this. While PAPs will be fully compensated, exploitation of the procedure and over-compensation will be minimised. Measures will be adopted to discourage the construction of 'fraudulent buildings' by landowners, uthulis or squatters simply in order to obtain compensation. Also, the project will not compensate for temporary selling platforms and the like which can bc uplifted, removed and re-located elsewhere without loss of value.

Institutional Arraiwements and Implementation Procedures The Deputy Commissioner's (DC) office in each District will acquire the land, acting on behalf of LGED as the requiring body. To support the DCs, and to ensure timely implementation in accordance with the LAAP, LGED will take a pro-active role. As a rural development agency with a social as well as technical perspective, and with offices in every District and Thana, LGED is well-placed to do this. The key LGED actors will be the District XENs, the Thana Engineers, and the Community Organisers at thana level. They will be supported by the PIO, whose incremental staffing includes a Sociologist in each of the 14 project Districts, and the Design, Supervision and Monitoring Consultants (DSMC), whose staffing includes two national Land Acquisition Field Advisers. The DSMC advisers will work full-time on land acquisition and will set up and operate the monitoring system. The incremental staffing also includes a Socio-Economist in PIO headquarters in Dhaka to work on land acquisition and participation aspects, and a Sociologist in LGED headquarters who, inter-alia, will develop LGED land acquisition practices. Union Parishads will be involved in the information campaign and grievance redressal procedure. This is the first Bank-financed project in Bangladesh where land acquisition procedures conforming to OD 4.30 will involve only government machinery, without availing of NGO support. As such it represents a major step forward in the institutionalization of land acquisition procedures. The implementation strategy allows ample time for land acquisition so that, for each year of full implementation of FRB works, it can be completed prior to the planned start of construction. The annual implementation schedule (Figure 1) allows a 13 month period for land acquisition up to the end of the three month eviction period, so that land is available for physical occupation by LGED prior to completion of road construction contract tendering. The schedule allows some slack for delays in the process. At the time of submission of the case to the DC, the DSMC will make a photographic record of the road, to document the pre-existence of buildings and trees on the alignment, as one measure to discourage 'fraudulent' compensation claims. A Joint On-Site Inventory and Verification will be carried out, involving the LAO, LGED, the DSMC Field Adviser, and the PAPs. This will define and record the PAPs, the assets to be acquired, the losses, and any disputes over ownership of assets. People within the vicinity of the road will be informed in advance of the exercise. This inventory and verification will form the basis for all subsequent stages of the land acquisition, and for monitoring. The DSMC Field Adviser and the PIO will undertake a market survey in the area of each road to assess the values of agricultural, homestead and developed commercial land; of buildings; and of standing trees and perennial crops. LGED and the P10 will then negotiate with the DC with the aim of reaching agreement on assessed values that reflect full market values. If such agreement is not reached, and if the DC's assessed values are lower than LGED's market values, LGED will make additional, 'top up' payments directly to PAPs. Payment of compensation to PAPs will be made at Union headquarters, in order to avoid the problems that PAPs often face in travelling long distances to obtain small compensation amounts. LGED will assist the DC in arrangements to make these payments. There will be some cases, where ownership of assets is unresolved, or where legal disputes are in process, that will not be completed prior to physical occupation of the land.

 194 Annex 3.8 Page 8 of 10 5. Information, Assistance and Grievance Procedures LGED will disseminate information about the land acquisition and compensation process. The information campaign in the vicinity of each road, which will involve the Union Parishad and will include the posting of notices and the distribution of leaflets, will start when the case is submitted to the DC. LGED will inform people that it is intended to acquire land. It will advise them of the procedures to be adopted and of the assets and losses that will be compensated (and of those that will not be compensated); of the persons entitled to compensation; of their rights and the steps that they should take to protect those rights; and of the assistance available from LGED to resolve problems and grievamces. During the Joint On-Site Inventory and Verification PAPs will again be advised of the procedures and of the support available from LGED. After the issue of Notice No.7, PAPs will be informed of compensation payments arrangements. At the time payments are made, PAPs will be informed of the time they have to vacate the land, and of the entitlement to salvage certain assets. LGED will assist PAPs to resolve queries and redress grievances. The grievance redressal procedure will operate through a committee in each Thana chaired by the Thana Engineer and comprising the District Sociologist and a member of the Union Parishad, which will meet regularly (about twice per month) at advertised times at the TE's office, when PAPs can formally present and discuss their queries and grievances. PAPs can ask a Union Parishad member to assist them. This committee will resolve some matters, and will determine that certain grievances are not legitimate. Where necessary, the committee will ask the District Sociologist, assisted by the DSMC Field Adviser, to follow-up. This may involve field investigations on-site with the PAP and his/her Union Parishad representative. The committee will then meet again with the PAP to review the findings of the investigation. For legitimate grievances which the committee is unable to resolve, a report will be submitted to the XEN, who will take further steps to resolve the grievance and if necessary will submit a formal request to the DC to consider the matter. The Thana Engineer will maintain a register of all queries and grievances presented to the committee, and of the actions taken and decisions made. This grievance procedure will not replace the existing legal appeal process, but will minimise the number of cases that reach the stage of legal action and will expedite the resolution of problems. 6. Monitoring and Reporting Procedure The DSM consultants, working with the PIO Sociologist, will monitor the progress and performance of land acquisition. The project Annual Plan of Operations (APO) will include targets for objectively verifiable indicators of progress of land acquisition. Monitoring and reporting will be based on comparison of actual progress on each road with these targets. Key progress indicators will be: * Date of submission of land acquisition case to DC * Date of completion of land market survey * Number of plots acquired The Joint On-Site Inventory and Verification will form the basis for monitoring performance. A computerised data-base will be set up for each road to record information for each identified PAP. It will then be used to track the performance of land acquisition as implementation proceeds. Performance will be monitored in terms of
 195 Annex 3.8 Page 9 of 10 * Numbers of PAPs * Characteristics of PAPs * Nature and level of impact * Value of compensation due to PAPs * Status of payment of compensation to PAPs * Progress of owners of homestead land, business proprietors, uthulis and squatters in re- location * Resolution of grievances * Numbers of legally disputed and other unresolved cases * Compliance with the eviction period The project will report twice per year on progress and performance. This will be incorporated into the relevant project quarterly progress reports. The DSMC, as part of their input to the SEM&E activities, and in collaboration with PIO and LGED SEM&E staff, will undertake broader studies of the impact of land acquisition on affected persons. The IDA and SDC will review the progress and performance by LGED of land acquisition as part of project supervision. About once per year, as required by IDA/SDC, an independent review of compliance by LGED of the policies set out in the LAAP will be carried out. 7. Budget The costs of land acquisition have been estimated using the data on quantities from the Preliminary Inventory Survey, and the findings from the LAA on market values of assets. Table 3 details the direct cost by District for acquisition of land, buildings and trees. The total estimated cost is Taka 150.8 million (US$3.77 million), or 7.3% of total FRB improvement and upgrading costs. The total cost is based on broad estimates of unit values of assets, and given this degree of uncertainty a 25% physical contingency has been included for land acquisition. Land acquisition will be 100% GOB financed. Table 3 also details the overhead and administrative costs of implementing the land acquisition process in accordance with the LAAP. The estimated cost is Taka 16.1 million (US$0.4 million), about 11% of the direct cost of land acquisition. In addition, some permanent LGED District and Thana staff will spend time on land acquisition matters. The total direct, overhead and administrative cost of land acquisition, including physical and price contingencies, is estimated at Taka 219.3 million (US$5.5 million).

 197 Annex 3.9 Page 1 of 6 BANGLADESH SECOND RURAL ROADS AND MARKETS IMPROVEMENT AND MAINTENANCE PROJECT SECTORAL ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT: SUMMARY' 1. Introduction The project is not expected to have a major impact on the physical or ecological environment. No new road alignments are involved. The proposed works are improvement, upgrading and maintenance of existing roads and will have positive environmental impacts - the provision of drainage structures will reduce waterlogging; bitumen surfacing will eliminate the dust hazard; the hard shoulders will improve safety; road safety measures will be applied to reduce congestion and accidents; and trees will be planted on the embankment slopes of all project roads, more than compensating for tree felling during construction. The physical environment, health standards and quality of life in the markets and ghats will be improved through provision of free-draining paved areas, hygienic latrines, garbage disposal facilities and potable water supplies. Bio-gas generators will be installed at markets to process solid waste. The use of labour-intensive construction and maintenance methods, and of local materials provides a sound environmental approach, and the use of environmentally-friendly construction materials will be promoted, including bitumen emulsion which eliminates the need for firewood to heat bitumen. The environmental category for this project is Category B. LGED has carried out an environmental impact study with assistance from the preparation consultants, based on LGED environmental guidelines, to identify all positive and negative project impacts and define the mitigation measures. This has been used to prepare a Sectoral Enviromnental Assessment. 2. Measures to Mitigate Negative Environmental Impacts of Road Improvements The potential negative impacts are primarily related to the FRB works. Table 1 details these - classified as High, Medium and Low risk - the proposed mitigation measures, and responsibilities for those measures, which will be applied to design, contracting, supervision, and operation of roads. Design Environmental considerations are incorporated into the technical design standards. Alignments will be adjusted to avoid cultural features. Sufficient structures will be provided, with adequate openings, to maintain natural drainage and navigability of channels - locations and sizes of structures will be determined based on field surveys, consultations with local people, and hydrological investigations. All improved embankments will be above the high flood level, constructed from suitable soil and mechanically compacted, with rigorous testing. Cambers and embankment slopes are specified to shed surface water and maintain soil stability, and erosion protection measures will be applied where necessary. All roads will be constructed with hard shoulders on each side of the pavement, and road safety signs and warning markers will be installed. Road safety measures will be incorporated at junctions, blackspots and adjacent to markets. Four project roads are within wildlife sanctuaries (Bhawal, Bil Bhatia and Chalan Beel) but project activities will not disturb the critical natural habitats. ' Details are in the Project file, in Document entitled "Sectoral Environmental Assessment for RRMIMP-2"
 Annex 3.9 198 Page 2 of 6 Contracting The contract documents incorporate environmental considerations. They detail the design standards and the procedures for testing of soil and compaction. They define the responsibilities of, and the procedures that will be adopted by, contractors for location and operation of site camps; location, excavation and reinstatement of borrow pits; temporary diversion of water channels and protection of unstable embankments; haulage of materials; storage and handling of materials; disposal of waste; and provision of road diversions and temporary traffic safety measures during construction. Supervision The compliance of contractors with the environmental requirements will be supervised by LGED, with the assistance of the DSM consultants. Soil and compaction testing will be a key element of supervision. LGED supervision staff will be trained in supervision of environmental aspects of construction works. Attention will be paid to mitigating negative impacts of disposal of waste materials, and the project will develop standards and indicators to monitor this. Trees will be planted on road embankment slopes, except on the inside of curves. Operation Routine maintenance will be applied to all project roads, including caretaking of the trees. This will mitigate against longer-term negative environmental impacts and sustain the environmental benefits. Maintenance of the smooth road surfaces will encourage the use of non-motorised transport (NMT). The pilot program to improve NMT will also promote the use of environmentally sound vehicles. The extension of routine and periodic maintenance to non-project roads will enhance the environment. Local government bodies will be encouraged to control development adjacent to the roads. 3. Measures to Mitigate Negative Environmental Impacts of Market and Ghat Improvements The environmental impacts of market and ghat improvements will be predominantly positive. Users will participate in the detailed design of the improvements to ensure that the numbers and types of facilities - including latrines and potable water supplies - meet local requirements. The main potential negative impact is if inadequate provision is made for the drainage and disposal of surface and waste water. The following measures will be taken to mitigate against this: * The DSM consultants will establish the design levels of the market and ghat paved areas to ensure that they are free-draining. Internal drains, designed for easy cleaning, will be provided in the market/ghat areas. Adequate, safe drain outfalls will be designed to ensure that there is no drainage congestion. * LGED and the DSM consultants will supervise construction works to ensure that the paved areas are built to the design levels and grades, and with the necessary outfalls. The project will train LGED staff in the supervision of market and ghat construction. * The project will develop the capability of the Market and Ghat Management Committees to maintain the markets and ghats. Improved procedures for cleaning the markets, maintaining free-drainage and disposing of garbage will be introduced.
 Annex 3.9 199 Page 3 of 6 Following the pilot initiative taken by LGED under the RDP-6 project, bio-gas generators will be installed in improved markets to process human, animal and vegetable waste to produce gas and compost. Management Conmnittees will be trained in the operation of the generators. 4. Monitoring Monitoring of short-term negative environmental impacts during the construction phase will be integrated into the supervision of the works. Longer-term environmental impacts of road improvement works will be monitored in four ways: * Monitoring of compliance with design standards and specifications will be part of the supervision of construction works. The regular inspection of roads for the planning and implementation of maintenance will generate data on their condition in respect of erosion, surface condition, state of tree plantations, blockage of drainage structures and condition of road signs and markings. Project SEM&E activities will include regular traffic counts on improved roads, generating data to monitor changes in the levels of motorised and non-motorised traffic. * Special surveys will be carried out of a sample of improved roads to monitor the extent to which any of the following negative impacts are occurring: - turbidity of roadside water; - drainage congestion during floods; - interference with boat communications; - pollution of surface and ground water; - disruption of fish migration and breeding; - encroachment of commercial and residential activities. * Monitoring of the environmental situation of improved markets and ghats will be incorporated into monitoring of the effectiveness of project actions to increase the capability of Market and Ghat Management Committees. The project will report annually on the environmental impact of its activities, and on the effectiveness of avoidance, mitigation and enhancement measures. The PIO staffing includes a full-time Environmental Engineer who will have direct responsibility for monitoring and reporting. 5. Institutional Strengthening LGED has a program to address environmental issues at the planning and design stages. It has guidelines on environmental assessment and two in-house environmental specialists. The guidelines are now being revised. LGED also has an environmental training program for XENs. The National Environmental Management Action Plan (NEMAP) will provide the national policy framework on environmental management within which LGED will operate in future. LGED would benefit from an in-house Environmental Unit to be responsible for environmental planning and management. The LGED training program on environmental impact assessment should be expanded
 200 Annex 3.9 Page 4 of 6 and made mandatory for all levels of personnel. Training in environmental matters should be extended to contractors, and to Union Parishads and Market and Ghat Management Committees. LGED should develop standard clauses on environmental aspects, similar to those adopted for the RRMIMP-2, for inclusion in technical specifications and conditions of contract, together with procedures for monitoring and supervision of mitigation measures during construction. The integration of environmental concerns into LGED planning procedures, and the increased participation of local people in all stages of infrastructure development, will enhance LGED's environmental performance.

doc.repnme: Bangladesh - Second Rural Roads and Markets Improvement and Maintenance Project
doc.abstracts: The objective of the Second Rural Roads and Markets Improvement and Maintenance Project is to help increase rural employment and incomes and reduce rural poverty. More specifically, the project will: a) help remove physical bottlenecks, improve quality, and reduce costs in rural transport and marketing; b) create employment and income-generating opportunities among the rural poor; c) promote participation of local communities and NGOs in project activities; and d) increase institutional capacity for efficient rural infrastructure management. The main components of the project are: a) improvement and upgrading of feeder roads; b) establishment and implementation of a road network maintenance system; c) culvert and bridge construction; d) physical improvement of rural markets; e) rehabilitation and construction of river jetties; f) pilot program to improve safety and efficiency of non motorized transport, particularly rickshaws; g) supply of road construction and maintenance equipment, vehicles, and office and training equipment; i) institutional and human resources development; and j) implementation support.
